taxonomicNotes: Nucifraga caryocatactes, N. hemispila and N. multipunctata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as N. caryocatactes following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Poecile cinctus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus cinctus.
Lophophanes cristatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus cristatus.
Cyanistes cyanus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus cyanus.
Aegithalos caudatus and A. glaucogularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. caudatus following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Phylloscopus bonelli and P. orientalis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. bonelli following Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Phylloscopus borealis, P. examinandus and P. xanthodryas (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. borealis following AERC TAC (2003), AOU (1998 & supplements), Christidis and Boles (2008), Cramp et al. (1977–1994), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

Previously placed in Sylvia (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019). Geographical variation slight and mostly clinal; subspecies merzbacheri intergrades widely with nominate in region of Urals and elsewhere. Two subspecies recognized.

Previously placed in Sylvia (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019). Geographical variation at least partly clinal; nominate subspecies grades into turcmenica in N Iran, but evidence for intergradation otherwise scant or not conclusive. Three subspecies recognized.

Previously placed in Sylvia (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019). Formerly included C. balearica as a subspecies (Cramp et al. 1977-1994, Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993); see that species. Monotypic.
Pastor roseus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Sturnus roseus.

Monotypic.

Previously listed as Sericornis citreogularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Norman et al. (2018). Despite reports (e.g. in HBW) that subspecies cairnsi is distinctive, it is only slightly smaller and shorter-tailed than nominate, and claim of different vocalizations appears unfounded, although it is less vocal than other subspecies and, unlike them, does not mimic other species. Subspecies intermedius intergrades with nominate and often synonymized with it. Three subspecies recognized.

Sericornis nouhuysi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously split into S. virgatus and S. nouhuysi following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993). S. nouhuysi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) also includes the race idenburgi, previously placed within S. beccarii.

Sericornis nouhuysi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously split into S. virgatus and S. nouhuysi following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993). S. nouhuysi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) also includes the race idenburgi, previously placed within S. beccarii.
Previously listed as Sericornis rufescens (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Norman et al. (2018). Replaces A. perspicillatus in the Vogelkop. Monotypic.

Previously listed as Calamanthus pyrrhopygius (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) and before that as Hylacola pyrrhopygia. Now moved back to Hylacola following Norman et al. (2018). Three subspecies recognized.
Previously listed as Calamanthus cautus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) and before that as Hylacola cauta. Now moved back to Hylacola following Norman et al. (2018). Four subspecies recognized.
Relationships uncertain. Genetic study needed; this taxon was not sampled in recent DNA study (Nyári and Joseph 2012). Monotypic.
Monachella muelleriana and M. coultasi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as M. muelleriana following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Plesiodryas albonotata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Poecilodryas albonotata.
Peneothello sigillata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Peneothello sigillatus.

Garritornis isidorei (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Pomatostomus isidorei.

Lanius isabellinus and L. phoenicuroides (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as L. isabellinus following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Lanius sphenocercus and L. giganteus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as L. sphenocercus following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Previously placed in monotypic genus Corvinella as C. corvina (del Hoyo & Collar 2016) but Fuchs et al. (2019) found that the sister genera Corvinella and Urolestes are nested within Lanius and recommended their synonymisation with the latter. Races intergrade, and intermediate individuals exist. Subspecies caliginosa sometimes merged with affinis (Dickinson & Christidis 2014). Proposed subspecies chapini (Kavirondo, in Kenya) included in affinis. Four subspecies recognized.

Previously placed in monotypic genus Urolestes as U. melanoleucos (del Hoyo & Collar 2016) but Fuchs et al. (2019) found that the sister genera Corvinella and Urolestes are nested within Lanius and recommended their synonymisation with the latter. Race angolensis included in nominate by some authors (Dickinson & Christidis 2014), as (more rarely) is expressus. Four subspecies recognized.

Eurocephalus ruppelli (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Eurocephalus ruppellii. Race erlangeri sometimes considered insufficiently differentiated, and species treated as monotypic (Dickinson & Christidis 2014). Other proposed subspecies are deckeni (Afgoi, in S Somalia), which is included in erlangeri, and fischeri (W of Kilimanjaro, in N Tanzania) and boehmi (NE of L Malawi, in S Tanzania), both synonymized with nominate. Two subspecies currently recognized.
Vireolanius leucotis and V. mikettae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as V. leucotis following SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Pachysylvia muscicapina (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Hylophilus muscicapinus.
Cinclosoma cinnamomeum and C. alisteri (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. cinnamomeum following Christidis & Boles (2008) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Daphoenositta chrysoptera and D. papuensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as D. chrysoptera following Christidis & Boles (2008) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Hylocitrea bonensis and H. bonthaina (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as H. bonensis following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Pachycephala cinerea (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as P. grisola.
Pitohui kirhocephalus, P. cerviniventris and P. uropygialis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. kirhocephalus following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Pseudorectes incertus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Pitohui incertus.
Platysmurus leucopterus and P. aterrimus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. leucopterus following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Cyanolyca armillata and C. quindiuna (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. armillata following SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Urocissa whiteheadi and U. xanthomelana (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as U. whiteheadi following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Dendrocitta occipitalis and D. cinerascens (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as D. occipitalis following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Corvus macrorhynchos and C. levaillantii (Sibley & Monroe [1990, 1993]) have been lumped into C. macrorhynchos following del Hoyo and Collar (2016).
Megalampitta gigantea (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Melampitta gigantea
Drepanornis albertisi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Epimachus albertisi.
Parotia carolae and P. berlepschi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. carolae following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Cracticus torquatus and C. argenteus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. torquatus following Christidis & Boles (2008) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Melloria quoyi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Cracticus quoyi.
Oriolus melanotis and O. finschi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as O. melanotis following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Previously placed in Edolisoma as E. parvulum (del Hoyo & Collar 2016). Placed tentatively in Lalage by some recent authors (Eaton et al. 2016), but more recent molecular study indicates that it should be returned to the genus Coracina (Pedersen et al. 2018), as previously listed. Monotypic.

Celebesica abbotti (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Coracina abbotti. Sometimes included in Edolisoma, and may be closest to E. parvulum. Placed in Lalage by some authors (Eaton et al. 2016). Monotypic.
Edolisoma anale (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Coracina analis.
Ceblepyris pectoralis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Coracina pectoralis.
Cyanograucalus azureus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Coracina azurea.
Ceblepyris cinereus and C. cucullatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Coracina cinerea following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Lalage typica (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Coracina typica.
Lalage newtoni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Coracina newtoni.
Edolisoma dohertyi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Coracina dohertyi.
Edolisoma sula (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Coracina sula.
Edolisoma morio (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Coracina morio.
Edolisoma ceramense (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Coracina ceramensis.
Edolisoma incertum (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Coracina incerta.

Edolisoma melas (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Coracina melas. Race batantae often merged with nominate; likewise, goodsoni and meeki included in nominate by some authors (Beehler & Pratt 2016). Species name often incorrectly given as melaena, but original name is a transliterated Greek word and thus remains invariable. Six subspecies currently recognized.
Edolisoma holopolium and E. pygmaeum (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Coracina holopolia following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Edolisoma ostentum (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Coracina ostenta.
Lalage polioptera (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Coracina polioptera.
Lalage fimbriata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Coracina fimbriata.
Lalage melanoleuca and L. minor (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as L. melanoleuca following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Lalage atrovirens and L. leucoptera (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as L. atrovirens following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Pericrocotus solaris and P. montanus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. solaris following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Chelidorhynx hypoxanthus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Rhipidura hypoxantha.
Rhipidura superciliaris and R. samarensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as R. superciliaris following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Rhipidura cyaniceps, R. sauli and R. albiventris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as R. cyaniceps following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Rhipidura albicollis and R. albogularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as R. albicollis following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Rhipidura javanica and R. nigritorquis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as R. javancia following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Rhipidura rufiventris, R. tenkatei, R. hoedti, R. bouruensis, R. obiensis, R. cinerea, R. assimilis, R. kordensis and R. isura (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as R. rufiventris following Christidis & Boles (2008) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Rhipidura fuliginosa and R. albiscapa (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as R. fuliginosa following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Turbott (1990).
Dicrurus paradiseus and D. lophorinus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as D. paradiseus following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Hypothymis azurea and H. puella (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as H. azurea following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Terpsiphone cinnamomea and T. unirufa (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. cinnamomea following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Symposiachrus rubiensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Monarcha rubiensis.
Carterornis pileatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Monarcha pileatus.
Carterornis castus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Monarcha castus.
Carterornis leucotis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Monarcha leucotis.
Symposiachrus mundus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Monarcha mundus.
Symposiachrus loricatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Monarcha loricatus.

Symposiachrus vidua (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Monarcha viduus.Symposiachrus vidua (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Monarcha viduus.
Myiagra azureocapilla and M. castaneigularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as M. azureocapilla following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Jønsson et al. (2018) establish that Cerulean Paradise-flycatcher Eutrichomyias rowleyi, Drongo Fantail Chaetorhynchus papuensis, Natewa Silktail Lamprolia klinesmithi and Taveuni Silktail L. victoriae belong in a separate ancient family, Lamproliidae, sister to the Rhipiduridae. This finding is accepted here.

Lamprolia victoriae and L. klinesmithi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as L. victoriae following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Grallina bruijnii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as G. bruijni.
Laniarius aethiopicus, L. nigerrimus and L. sublacteus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as L. aethiopicus following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Laniarius poensis and L. holomelas (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as L. poensis following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Chlorophoneus bocagei (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Telophorus bocagei.
Chlorophoneus sulfureopectus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Telophorus sulfureopectus.
Chlorophoneus olivaceus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Telophorus olivaceus.
Telophorus viridis and T. quadricolor (Sibley & Monroe [1990, 1993]) have been lumped into T. viridis following del Hoyo and Collar (2016).
Dyaphorophyia castanea and D. hormophora (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Platysteira castanea following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Dyaphorophyia concreta and D. ansorgei (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Platysteira concreta following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Tephrodornis virgatus and T. sylvicola (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. gularis following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Cyanolanius madagascarinus and C. comorensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. madagascarinus following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Stizorhina fraseri and S. finschi (del Hoyo and collar 2016) were previously lumped as S. fraseri following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993).
Monticola imerina (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as M. imerinus following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Previously placed in monotypic genus Geomalia (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but shown by Olsson & Alström (2013) to be firmly nested within the current genus. Birds from N & SE Sulawesi described as subspecies matinangensis, but diagnostic characters weak and not apparent in all material. Monotypic.
Geokichla wardii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Zoothera wardii.
Geokichla sibirica (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Zoothera sibirica.

Zoothera mollissima and Z. griseiceps (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Z. mollissima following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993), which included the formerly overlooked Z. salimali (Alström et al. 2016)

Cichlopsis leucogenys, C. chubbi, C. peruviana and C. gularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. leucogenys following SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Turdus libonyana (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as T. libonyanus.
Turdus poliocephalus and T. niveiceos (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. poliocephalus following Christidis & Boles (2008) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Otocichla mupinensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Turdus mupinensis.

Turdus plumbeus, T. rubripes and T. ardosiaceus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. plumbeus following AOU (1998 & supplements), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Turdus chiguanco and T. anthracinus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. chiguanco following SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Turdus ignobilis, T. debilis and T. arthuri (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. ignobilis following SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Brachypteryx leucophris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Brachypteryx leucophrys.
Chamaetylas poliophrys (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Pseudalethe poliophrys.
Chamaetylas fuelleborni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Pseudalethe fuelleborni.
Agricola pallidus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Bradornis pallidus.
Agricola infuscatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Bradornis infuscatus.
Melaenornis chocolatinus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Dioptrornis chocolatinus.
Melaenornis fischeri (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Dioptrornis fischeri.
Melaenornis brunneus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Dioptrornis brunneus.

Previously listed as Melaenornis silens (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) and before that as Sigelus silens. Genetic analyses (Voelker et al. 2016) and clear differences in behaviour and ecology favour the return of this species to a monotypic genus. Two subspecies recognized.
Eumyias additus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Rhinomyias additus. Monotypic.
Cyornis brunneatus and C. nicobaricus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Rhinomyias brunneatus following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Cyornis olivaceus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Rhinomyias olivaceus.
Cyornis colonus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Rhinomyias colonus.
Vauriella insignis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Rhinomyias insignis.
Vauriella albigularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Rhinomyias albigularis.
Heteroxenicus stellatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Brachypteryx stellata.

Previously listed as Bradornis boehmi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) and before that as Muscicapa boehmi but the genetic analysis of Voelker et al. (2016) suggests that it warrants its own genus Myopornis. Monotypic.
Fraseria olivascens (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Muscicapa olivascens.
Bradornis comitatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Muscicapa comitata.
Fraseria caerulescens (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Muscicapa caerulescens.
Fraseria griseigularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Myioparus griseigularis.

Ficedula hodgsoni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) - Pygmy Blue-flycatcher - was previously placed in the genus Muscicapella following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993). Ficedula erithacus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) - Slaty-backed Flycatcher - was previously listed as F. hodgsonii following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Anthipes monileger (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Ficedula monileger.
Anthipes solitaris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Ficedula solitaris.

Previously listed as Cyornis hoevelli (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but unpublished genetic data (Frank Rheindt in litt. via WGAC) clearly place all Cyornis east of Wallace’s Line within Eumyias. To prevent the common names ‘jungle-flycatcher’ or ‘blue-flycatcher’ being applied to species in two different genera, these species are given the common name ‘warbling-flycatcher’. Sometimes placed in genus Niltava. Monotypic

Previously listed as Cyornis hyacinthinus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but unpublished genetic data (Frank Rheindt in litt. via WGAC) clearly place all Cyornis east of Wallace’s Line within Eumyias. To prevent the common names ‘jungle-flycatcher’ or ‘blue-flycatcher’ being applied to species in two different genera, these species are given the common name ‘warbling-flycatcher’. Sometimes placed in genus Niltava. Population on Roti (off SW Timor) probably belongs to nominate subspecies (Eaton et al. 2016). Two subspecies recognized.
Cyornis rufigastra and C. djampeanus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. rufigastra following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Larvivora sibilans (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Luscinia following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Larvivora cyane (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Luscinia following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 & supplements); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Previously listed as Oreocossypha isabellae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) and before that as Cossypha isabellae, but unpublished genetic data (Per Alström, in litt via WGAC) clearly place isabellae as sister to Cossyphicula roberti. Has sometimes been placed in genus Dryocichloides or in Sheppardia. Two subspecies recognized.
Dessonornis archeri (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Cossypha archeri.
Dessonornis humeralis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Cossypha humeralis.
Cossypha albicapillus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as C. albicapilla
Tychaedon quadrivirgata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Erythropygia quadrivirgata.
Tychaedon barbata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Erythropygia barbata.
Cercotrichas leucophrys (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Erythropygia leucophrys.
Cercotrichas paena (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Erythropygia paena.
Tychaedon coryphoeus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Erythropygia coryphaeus.

Previously listed as Melaenornis herero (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) and before that as Namibornis herero. Genetic analyses (Voelker et al. 2016) and clear differences in behaviour and ecology favour the return of this species to a monotypic genus. Resembles Bradornis in features such as nest structure, nest-site, eggs, and nestlings’ begging call, yet recalls some Oenanthe in voice, habits, and appearance of fledglings. Monotypic.

Previously listed as Kittacincla nigra (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) before that as Copsychus niger. Moved back to Copsychus on the basis of unpublished genetic data (Per Alström, in litt. via WGAC) that support a broad Copsychus. Sister-species to C. cebuensis (Lim et al. 2010). Has sometimes been considered closely related to, and possibly conspecific with, Copsychus saularis, but a close relationship is rejected by genetic data (Lim et al. 2010). Monotypic.

Previously listed as Kittacincla cebuensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016), and before that as Copsychus cebuensis. Moved back to Copsychus on the basis of unpublished genetic data (Per Alström, in litt. via WGAC) that support a broad Copsychus. Sister-species to C. niger (Lim et al. 2010). Monotypic.
Phoenicurus coeruleocephala (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as P. caeruleocephala following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Phoenicurus leucocephalus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Chaimarrornis following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Phoenicurus fuliginosus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Rhyacornis and listed as R. fuliginosa following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Campicoloides bifasciatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Oenanthe and listed as O. bifasciata following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Myrmecocichla monticola (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Oenanthe following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Previously treated with O. lugentoides and O. lugens as O. lugens (del Hoyo and Collar 2016), before which it was treated as a separate species following AERC TAC (2003); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993). Differs from both those species genetically (Schweizer and Burri 2019), and in smaller size (allow 2), deeper black coloration (in all cases except O. lugens warriae), more extensive black on sides (in all cases except O. lugens warriae), less extensive white on nape (in all cases except O. lugens warriae), narrower white on rump & uppertail (with broader black terminal tail-band) (3), and smaller white patch on upperwing in flight (2). Two subspecies recognised.
Emarginata sinuata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Cercomela following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Emarginata schlegelii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Cercomela following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Emarginata tractrac (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Cercomela following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Oenanthe scotocerca (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Cercomela following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Oenanthe melanura (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Cercomela following AERC TAC (2003); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Pinarochroa sordida (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Cercomela following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Oenanthe albifrons (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Myrmecocichla following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Lamprotornis iris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Coccycolius iris.
Notopholia corusca (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Lamprotornis corruscus.

Lamprotornis fischeri (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Spreo fischeri.
Lamprotornis bicolor (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Spreo bicolor.

Lamprotornis unicolor (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Cosmopsarus unicolor.
Saroglossa spilopterus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Saroglossa spiloptera.
Sturnornis albofrontatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Sturnus albofrontatus.
Sturnia malabarica (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Sturnus malabaricus.
Agropsar sturninus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Sturnus sturninus.
Sturnia sinensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Sturnus sinensis.
Spodiopsar cineraceus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Sturnus cineraceus.
Gracupica nigricollis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Sturnus nigricollis.
Acridotheres burmannicus and A. leucocpehalus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Sturnus burmannicus following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Acridotheres grandis and A. javanicus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. grandis following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Mino dumontii and M. kreffti (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously listed as M. dumontii following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Goodfellowia miranda (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Basilornis mirandus.
Sitta pusilla and S. insularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as S. pusilla following AOU (1998 & supplements), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Sitta leucopsis and S. przewalskii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as S. leucopsis following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Salpornis spilonota and S. salvadori (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as S. spilonotus following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Cistothorus platensis and C. stellaris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. platensis (see AOU [1998 & supplements]; SACC [2005 & updates]; Sibley & Monroe [1990, 1993]; Stotz et al. [1996]).

Pheugopedius euophrys and P. schulenbergi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Thryothorus euophrys following SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Pheugopedius eisenmanni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Thryothorus eisenmanni.
Cantorchilus semibadius (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Thryothorus semibadius.
Cantorchilus superciliaris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Thryothorus superciliaris.
Cantorchilus griseus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Thryothorus griseus.

Henicorhina leucophrys and H. anachoreta (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as H. leucophrys following AOU (1998 & supplements), SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Cyphorhinus thoracicus and C. dichrous (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. thoracicus following SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Anthoscopus caroli and A. sylviella (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. caroli following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993).
Poecile carolinensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus carolinensis.
Poecile superciliosus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus superciliosus.
Poecile davidi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus davidi.
Poecile hudsonicus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus hudsonicus.
Poecile rufescens (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus rufescens.
Periparus rufonuchalis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus rufonuchalis.
Periparus rubidiventris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus rubidiventris.
Pardaliparus venustulus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus venustulus.
Pardaliparus elegans (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus elegans.
Pardaliparus amabilis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus amabilis.
Lophophanes dichrous (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus dichrous.
Melaniparus albiventris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus albiventris.
Melaniparus leuconotus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus leuconotus.
Melaniparus funereus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus funereus.
Melaniparus rufiventris and M. pallidiventris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Parus rufiventris following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993).
Melaniparus fringillinus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus fringillinus.
Melaniparus fasciiventer (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus fasciiventer.
Melaniparus thruppi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus thruppi.
Melaniparus griseiventris (del Hoyo   and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus   griseiventris.
Melaniparus cinerascens (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus cinerascens.
Melaniparus afer (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus afer.
Machlolophus spilonotus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus spilonotus.
Machlolophus holsti (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus holsti.
Aegithalos concinnus, A. iredalei and A. annamensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. concinnus following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Orochelidon murina (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Notiochelidon murina.
Orochelidon flavipes (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Notiochelidon flavipes.

Riparia paludicola, R. cowani and R. chinensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as R. paludicola following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Ptyonoprogne fuligula and P. rufigula (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Hirundo fuligula following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Ptyonoprogne concolor (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Hirundo concolor.
Cecropis cucullata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Hirundo cucullata.
Cecropis senegalensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Hirundo senegalensis.
Petrochelidon perdita (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Hirundo perdita.
Petrochelidon preussi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Hirundo preussi.
Petrochelidon rufigula (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Hirundo rufigula.
Petrochelidon fluvicola (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Hirundo fluvicola.
Petrochelidon ariel (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Hirundo ariel.

A comprehensive phylogenetic analysis of bulbuls (Shakya and Sheldon 2017) has indicated that Striated Bulbul is sister to a large clade of several robust genera and is moved to its own genus, Alcurus Blyth, 1842. Therefore it becomes Alcurus striatus (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2019).

A comprehensive phylogenetic analysis of bulbuls (Shakya and Sheldon 2017) recommended transferring Cream-striped Bulbul to Hemixos, which results in Hemixos leucogrammicus (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BIrdLife International 2019).
Microtarsus melanoleucos (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Pycnonotus melanoleucos.
Brachypodius priocephalus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Pycnonotus priocephalus.
Brachypodius atriceps and B. fuscoflavescens (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Pycnonotus atriceps following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

A comprehensive phylogenetic analysis of bulbuls (Shakya and Sheldon 2017) recommends that the five species previously lumped as Pycnonotus melanicterus be moved into the genus Rubigula (Blyth, 1845), consequently R. melanictera, R. gularis, R. flaviventris, R. dispar and R. montis (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2019) are accepted.

Pycnonotus melanicterus, P. gularis, P. flaviventris, P. dispar and P. montis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. melanicterus following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

A comprehensive phylogenetic analysis of bulbuls (Shakya and Sheldon 2017) recommends that Pycnonotus squamatus, P. cyaniventris and P. erythropthalmos are moved into the genus Ixidia Blyth, 1846 ('Ixidea' is an error in Shakya and Sheldon 2017, citing Fishpool and Tobias [2005] who use Ixidia), consequently I. squamata, I. cyaniventris and I. erythropthalmos (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2019) are accepted.

A comprehensive phylogenetic analysis of bulbuls (Shakya and Sheldon 2017) recommends that Pycnonotus squamatus, P. cyaniventris and P. erythropthalmos are moved into the genus Ixidia Blyth, 1846 ('Ixidea' is an error in Shakya and Sheldon 2017, citing Fishpool and Tobias [2005] who use Ixidia), consequently I. squamata, I. cyaniventris and I. erythropthalmos (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2019) are accepted.
Euptilotus eutilotus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Pycnonotus eutilotus.
Poliolophus urostictus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Pycnonotus urostictus.
Pycnonotus finlaysoni and P. davisoni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. finlaysoni following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Pycnonotus flavescens and P. leucops (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. flavescens following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Pycnonotus plumosus and P. cinereifrons (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. plumosus following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

A comprehensive phylogenetic analysis of bulbuls (Shakya and Sheldon 2017) recommends that Pycnonotus squamatus, P. cyaniventris and P. erythropthalmos are moved into the genus Ixidia Blyth, 1846 ('Ixidea' is an error in Shakya and Sheldon 2017, citing Fishpool and Tobias [2005] who use Ixidia), consequently I. squamata, I. cyaniventris and I. erythropthalmos (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2019) are accepted.
Stelgidillas gracilirostris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Andropadus gracilirostris.
Arizelocichla tephrolaema (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Andropadus tephrolaemus.
Atimastillas flavicollis and A. falvigula (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Chlorocichla flavicollis following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Phyllastrephus albigularis and P. viridiceps (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. albigularis following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Xanthomixis cinereiceps (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Bernieria cinereiceps.
Alophoixus ochraceus and A. ruficrissus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. ochraceus following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Eight species, Hypsipetes affinis, H. longirostris, H. mysticalis, H. harterti, H. aureus, H. platenae, H. chloris and H. lucasi have been moved from the genus Thapsinllas (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) following a comprehensive phylogeny of the bulbuls (Shakya and Sheldon 2017). All were previously lumped as Alophoixus affinis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Iole charlottae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as I. olivacea.
Acritillas indica (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Iole indica.
Iole palawanensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Ixos palawanensis.
Hypsipetes everetti, H. catarmanensis and H. haynaldi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Ixos everetti following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Hemixos flavala , H. cinereus and H. connectens (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as H. flavala following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Ixos mcclellandii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Hypsipetes mcclellandii.
Hypsipetes leucocephalus and H. ganeesa (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as H. leucocephalus following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Ixos nicobariensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Hypsipetes nicobariensis.

Hypsipetes thompsoni (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2019) was previously listed as Cerasophila thompsoni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016). Following a comprehensive phylogenetic analysis of the bulbuls (Shakya and Sheldon 2017), the species has been returned to the genus in which it was formerly placed.
Cisticola aberrans and C. bailunduensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. aberrans following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993).
Cisticola nana (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as C. nanus.

The genus Rhopophilus has been moved from the family Sylviidae to Paradoxornithidae following Cai et al. (2019).

Until recently (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was considered conspecific with R. albosuperciliaris following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) but treated as separate species following Leader et al. (2013) (see related note/s). Proposed subspecies leptorhynchus (from E Qinghai and Gansu) rather weakly defined; recent review (Leader et al. 2013) supports treatment as synonym. Monotypic.
Prinia flaviventris and P. sonitans (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. flaviventris following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Schistolais leucopogon (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Prinia leucopogon.
Oreophilais robertsi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Prinia robertsi.
Prinia erythroptera (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Heliolais erythropterus.
Oreolais pulcher (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Oreolais pulchra.
Apalis flavida and A. flavocincta (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. flavida following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993).
Prinia rufifrons (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Spiloptila rufifrons.
Camaroptera brachyura and C. harterti (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. brachyura following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993).
Camaroptera chloronota and C. toroensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. chloronota following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Calamonastes simplex (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Camaroptera simplex.
Calamonastes undosus and C. stierlingi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Camaroptera undosa following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993).
Calamonastes fasciolatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Camaroptera fasciolata.
Zosterops melanocephalus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Speirops melanocephalus.
Zosterops brunneus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Speirops brunneus.
Heleia wallacei (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Zosterops wallacei.
Zosterops minor and Z. chrysolaemus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Z. minor following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Zosterops fuscicapilla and Z. crookshanki (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Z. fuscicapilla following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Heleia squamiceps (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Lophozosterops squamiceps.
Heleia goodfellowi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Lophozosterops goodfellowi.
Heleia pinaiae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Lophozosterops pinaiae.
Heleia squamifrons (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Oculocincta squamifrons.
Chlorocharis emiliae has been moved into the genus Zosterops after Lim et al. (2019) confirmed that its genetic position is subsumed within Zosterops.
Zosterops superciliosus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Woodfordia superciliosa.
Cettia castaneocoronata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Tesia castaneocoronata.
Hemitesia pallidipes (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Cettia pallidipes.
Horornis annae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Cettia annae.
Horornis parens (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Cettia parens.
Horornis ruficapilla (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Cettia rufocapilla.
Previously placed in Bradypterus (del Hoyo & Collar 2016) but moved to Locustella following Alström et al. (2018). Two subspecies recognized.
Cryptillas victorini (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Bradypterus victorini.
Locustella tacsanowskia (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Bradypterus tacsanowskia.
Locustella luteoventris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Bradypterus luteoventris.
Locustella caudata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Bradypterus caudata.
Bradypterus brunneus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Dromaeocercus brunneus.
Nesillas typica (Schulenberg et al. [1993]) and N. longicaudata (Sibley & Monroe [1990, 1993]) have been lumped into N. typica following del Hoyo and Collar (2016).

As part of their overhaul of the Locustellidae (see below) Alström et al. (2018) introduced the generic name Helopsaltes to cover the monophyletic group of Locustella warbler species ochotensis, pleskei, certhiola, pryeri, fasciolata and amnicola (del Hoyo & Collar 2016). They found no morphological diagnostic characters, but identified a clear difference in voice. 
Has been considered elsewhere to be conspecific with either or both of H. ochotensis and H. pleskei (see both). Subspecies sparsimstriata intergrades with nominate in S Siberia (L Baikal area). Birds of Amurland (SE Siberia and NE China) sometimes separated as subspecies minor (Kennerley & Pearson 2010). Four subspecies recognized.

As part of their overhaul of the Locustellidae (see below) Alström et al. (2018) introduced the generic name Helopsaltes to cover the monophyletic group of Locustella warbler species ochotensis, pleskei, certhiola, pryeri, fasciolata and amnicola (del Hoyo and Collar 2016). They found no morphological diagnostic characters, but identified a clear difference in voice.Has elsewhere been considered conspecific with either or both of H. certhiola and H. pleskei. Hybridizes with former in E Russia (in lower Amur area and N Sakhalin), where apparently maintains stable intergrade populations, but elsewhere in range it exhibits a constant and distinctive suite of plumage, voice and behavioural characters. Birds of Kamchatka and N Kurils sometimes separated as subspecies subcerthiola (Kennerley & Pearson 2010), but here considered indistinguishable from birds elsewhere in range. Monotypic.

Initially considered a subspecies of A. vaughani; unlike latter (which does not sing), however, it is a good singer, and differs also in measurements, in plumage coloration, in showing no tendency towards leucism, and in DNA (Cibois et al. 2011a). Two subspecies recognized.
Arundinax aedon (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Acrocephalus aedon.
Iduna natalensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Chloropeta natalensis.
Iduna similis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Chloropeta similis.
Orthotomus castaneiceps and O. chloronotus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as O. castaneiceps following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Has elsewhere been previously considered conspecific with O. sepium, but they behave as separate species where they meet (in Java) and are genetically distinct (Sheldon et al. 2012). For some time there was much confusion over the names of these two and O. sericeus; consequently, some statements in recent literature are incorrect or require reconfirmation. Nine subspecies recognized.
Eremomela pusilla and E. canescens (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumedp as E. pusilla following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993).
Sylvietta brachyura and S. leucopsis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as S. brachyura following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Phylloscopus poliogenys (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Seicercus poliogenys.
Phylloscopus castaniceps (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Seicercus castaniceps.
Phylloscopus sumatrensis and P. grammiceps (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Seicercus grammiceps following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Has been included by others in Dromaeocercus, together with Bradypterus brunneus, on account of similarity in their tail structure, also in the monotypic genus Amphilais (del Hoyo & Collar 2016) but shown by Alstrom et al. (2018) to nest clearly within Bradypterus. Monotypic.
Cincloramphus timoriensis and C. macrurus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Megalurus timoriensis following Christidis & Boles (2008); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Poodytes carteri (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Eremiornis carteri.

Previously listed as Megalurulus mariae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) and before that as Megalurulus mariei but reassigned to Cincloramphus following Alström et al. (2018). Species name has frequently been spelt mariei; internal evidence “C’est à M. Marie...que nous nous faisons un devoir de le dédier...” could be used to justify this emendation; however, original spelling may have been based on Latinized form of Marie (“Maria”), so original spelling stands (Dickinson and Christidis 2014). Monotypic.

Previously sometimes considered conspecific with S. platyurus but shown by Alström et al. (2018) to be better placed in its own genus. Subspecies alexinae intergrades with nominate. Two subspecies recognized.

Previously sometimes considered conspecific with African C. brevirostris but that was shown by Alström et al. (2018) to be better placed in its own genus. Distinct differences exist between birds from N of range (larger, duller and greyer above, contrasting reddish-brown wings, whiter below) and those from S (rather smaller, darker reddish-brown above, buff below); significance of this, which apparently is not due to plumage wear, unclear and requires investigation. Monotypic.
Previously treated as Garrulax perspicillatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cibois et al. (2018).  Has sometimes been placed in genus Dryonastes. Monotypic.

Previously treated as Garrulax pectoralis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cibois et al. (2018). Geographical variation mainly clinal. Proposed subspecies melanotis (E Himalayas E to N Myanmar) considered part of cline and merged with nominate. Form named pingi (C Yunnan, in S China) represents presumed hybrid between nominate and robini. Birds in SW Guangxi (S China) not assigned to subspecies. Five subspecies recognized.

The two closely related Sundaic species previously known as Black Laughingthrush Garrulax lugubris and Bare-headed Laughingthrush G. calvus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016), often formerly treated as conspecific, were subject to molecular analysis for the first time by Cai et al. (2019), who discovered that they actually belong in another babbler family, proving to be closer to the genus Pomatorhinus than Pomatorhinus is to Erythrogenys. Monotypic.
Previously treated as Garrulax nuchalis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cibois et al. (2018). Has elsewhere been treated as conspecific with P. chinensis. Monotypic.
Previously treated as Garrulax vassali (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cibois et al. (2018). Monotypic.

Previously treated as Garrulax davidi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cibois et al. (2018). Several further subspecies proposed, including funebris (from NE Qinghai), experrectus (NW Gansu) and chinganicus (N Hebei E to Inner Mongolia), but differences negligible or undetectable in larger samples. Two subspecies recognized.
Previously listed as Garrulax sukatschewi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cibois et al. (2018). Monotypic.

Previously listed as Garrulax lunulatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cibois et al. (2018). Has elsewhere been treated as conspecific with I. bieti. Two subspecies recognized.

Previously treated as Garrulax sannio (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cibois et al. (2018). Has elsewhere recently been treated in genus Dryonastes. Four subspecies recognized.
Trochalopteron subunicolor (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Garrulax subunicolor.
Trochalopteron variegatum (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Garrulax variegatus.
Trochalopteron morrisonianum (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Garrulax morrisonianus.
Trochalopteron milnei (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Garrulax milnei.
Liocichla phoenicea and L. ripponi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as L. phoenicea following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Previously placed in Trichastoma (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to this genus following Cai et al. (2019). Two subspecies recognised.

Previously placed in Trichastoma (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to this genus following Cai et al. (2019).
Geographical variation partly clinal; proposed subspecies connectens, from NC Sulawesi, and improbatum (of which sordidum is a synonym), from SE, considered to represent part of this cline, and therefore merged with rufofuscum. Subspecies finschi, however, distinctive: differs in its much more restricted white throat (2) and fulvous-buff vs greyish-white lower throat to vent, without contrasting darker flanks (3); study of voice, and what happens where this form and rufofuscum approach each other, therefore encouraged. Four subspecies recognized.
Previously placed in Trichastoma (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to this genus following Cai et al. (2019). Monotypic.

Previously placed in Trichastoma (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) and in Malacocincla but moved to this genus following Cai et al. (2019). Perhaps conspecific with P. malaccense, but song very different. Monotypic.
Illadopsis rufipennis and I. distans (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as I. rufipennis following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Erythrogenys hypoleucos (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Pomatorhinus hypoleucos.
Erythrogenys erythrogenys (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Pomatorhinus erythrogenys.
Pomatorhinus ferruginosus and P. phayrei (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. ferruginosus following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Pomatorhinus superciliaris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Xiphirhynchus superciliaris.

Previously placed in genus Rimator (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019). Rimator danjoui and R. naungmungensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Jabouilleia danjoui following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993). The treatment of N. naungmungensis as a subspecies of present species remains plausible, despite subsequent publications in support of species status (Rappole et al. 2008, Renner and Rappole 2011). In Vietnam, birds in NE Tonkin (with stronger black malar area and bold black-and-white feathering on belly) represent an as yet undescribed subspecies, and those in Central Highlands of S part of C Annam (with brown of plumage colder and darker, rufous areas duller and paler, underparts and bill roughly intermediate between those of other subspecies) another such. Two subspecies currently recognized.

Previously listed as Turdinus rufipectus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but Cai et al. (2019) suggested it might be better placed in the current genus (although this taxon was not sampled in their analysis). Monotypic.
Turdinus marmoratus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as T. marmorata.

Previously listed as Turdinus crispifrons (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but Cai et al. (2019) found it more closely related to Malacocincla and revived the genus Gypsophila for this and allied species. Formerly treated as conspecific with G. calcicola following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993). Two subspecies recognized.

Previously listed as Turdinus brevicaudatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but Cai et al. (2019) found it more closely related to Malacocincla and revived the genus Gypsophila for this and allied species. Previously listed as Napothera brevicaudata following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Has been thought to be possibly conspecific with G. crassa. Subspecies remarkably diverse within rather narrow phenotypic confines, forming as many as five groups: (a) nominate and striatus (rufous below, broad throat-streaks); (b) stevensi and proximus (dark rich brown below, less distinct throat-streaks); (c) leucostictus (broad throat- and breast-streaks, to belly); (d) griseigularis (smallish with very vague throat-streaks, paler breast and belly); and (e) rufiventer (apparently richer rufous below with buff vs white wing-spots); however, vocally all groups appear very similar (Boesman 2016). Birds in N & E Myanmar and W Yunnan (China) sometimes separated as subspecies venningi, supposedly larger and more rufous, but fall within range of variation of nominate. Racial identity of birds in NW Laos uncertain, conditionally included in nominate. Seven subspecies recognized.

Previously listed as Turdinus crassus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but Cai et al. (2019) found it more closely related to Malacocincla and revived the genus Gypsophila for this and allied species. Formerly listed as Napothera crassa (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993). See G. brevicaudata. Monotypic.
Elachura formosa (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Spelaeornis and listed as S. formosus following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Neomixis striatigula and N. pallidior (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as N. striatigula following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Stachyris rufifrons (Robson [2000]) and S. ambigua (Sibley & Monroe [1990, 1993]) have been lumped together into Cyanoderma rufifrons following del Hoyo and Collar (2016)
Cyanoderma ruficeps (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Stachyris ruficeps.
Cyanoderma chrysaeum (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Stachyris chrysaea.
Sterrhoptilus nigrocapitatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Stachyris nigrocapitata.
Zosterornis whiteheadi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Stachyris whiteheadi.
Zosterornis nigrorum (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Stachyris nigrorum.
Stachyris strialata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Stachyris striolata.
Macronus striaticeps (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Macronous striaticeps.
Macronus ptilosus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Macronous ptilosus.

The genus Chrysomma has been moved from the family Sylviidae to Paradoxornithidae following Cai et al. (2019). 
Geographical variation clinal, from palest in W (subspecies hypoleucum) to darkest in E (nominate), merging through middle of Indian Subcontinent; birds from Nepal appear intermediate. Four subspecies recognized.

Moupinia poecilotis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Chrysomma poecilotis. Moved from Sylviidae to the family Paradoxornithidae following Cai et al. (2019).
Birds from NW Yunnan sometimes recognized as subspecies sordidior. Monotypic.

Previously listed as Chatarrhaea longirostris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019). Formerly listed as Turdoides longirostris. Birds reported from SW Myanmar not yet assigned to subspecies. Two subspecies recognized.
Argya malcolmi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Turdoides malcolmi.
Argya fulva (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Turdoides fulva.
Argya subrufa (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Turdoides subrufa.

Previously placed in Turdoides (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019). Prior to that treated as conspecific with A. somervillei following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993). Has been treated as conspecific with A. rufescens.
Proposed subspecies orissae (from E India) treated as synonym of nominate. Four subspecies recognized.
Previously placed in Turdoides (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019). Two subspecies recognized.
Turdoides reinwardtii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as T. reinwardii.

Previously treated as Garrulax waddelli (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cibois et al. (2018). Prior to this change the taxon was listed as Babax waddelli. Proposed subspecies lumsdeni, described from Le La, on SE Xizang border with Arunachal Pradesh (NE India), merged with nominate. Two subspecies recognized.

Previously treated as Garrulax koslowi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cibois et al. (2018). Prior to this change the taxon was previously listed as Babax koslowi. Two subspecies recognized.
Leiothrix argentauris and L. laurinae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as L. argentauris following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Actinodura ramsayi and A. radcliffei (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. ramsayi following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Sibia nipalensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Actinodura nipalensis.
Sibia souliei (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Actinodura souliei.
Sibia morrisoniana (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Actinodura morrisoniana.
Siva cyanouroptera (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Minla cyanouroptera.
Chrysominla strigula (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Minla strigula.
Schoeniparus variegaticeps  (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Alcippe variegaticeps.

The genus Fulvetta has been moved from the family Sylviidae to Paradoxornithidae following Cai et al. (2019). Fulvetta striaticollis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Alcippe striaticollis. Monotypic.

The genus Fulvetta has been moved from the family Sylviidae to Paradoxornithidae following Cai et al. (2019). Fulvetta ludlowi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Alcippe ludlowi. Monotypic.
Schoeniparus rufogularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Alcippe rufogularis.
Schoeniparus dubius (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Alcippe dubia.

Following Cai et al. (2019), all members of genus Alcippe now moved to their own family Alcippeidae. Geographical variation slight, despite number of named subspecies. Species subject to several molecular analyses in recent years (Qu et al. 2015, Song et al. 2009, Zou et al. 2007), the first resulting in suggestions for possible new species limits, but an error in the identity of a sample rendered the exercise uncertain (Pilgrim et al. 2009); rearrangement made in partial response to molecular findings (Robson 2008) rendered untenable by subsequent groupings of clades (Qu et al. 2015); moreover, vocal differences among all subspecies slight, with fratercula and yunnanensis emerging as a unit marginally more distinctive than others (Boesman 2016). Eight subspecies recognized.
Previously placed in genus Parophasma (del Hoyo & Collar 2016) but shown by Cai et al. (2019) to belong to current genus. Monotypic.
Leioptila annectens (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Heterophasia annectens.

This species, previously listed as Yuhina diademata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was found by Cai et al. (2019) to be sister to all other members of the timaliine family Zosteropidae, who therefore created for it the genus Parayuhina. Two subspecies recognized.

The genus Paradoxornis has been moved from the family Sylviidae to Paradoxornithidae following Cai et al. (2019).
Previously placed in Cholornis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016), before which it was listed as Paradoxornis paradoxus and is now moved back to this genus following Cai et al. (2019). Although taipaiensis was first mooted as a distinct subspecies in 1937, it was not formally described as such until 36 years later (Cheng Tsohsin et al. 1973). Two subspecies recognized.

The genus Paradoxornis has been moved from the family Sylviidae to Paradoxornithidae following Cai et al. (2019). Previously placed in Cholornis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016), before which it was listed as Paradoxornis unicolor and is now moved back to this genus following Cai et al. (2019). Monotypic.

The genus Paradoxornis has been moved from the family Sylviidae to Paradoxornithidae following Cai et al. (2019). Elsewhere has been treated as conspecific with P. guttaticollis by some authors, but is morphometrically quite distinct and differs in vocalizations and, especially, in habitat requirements; ranges overlap (or formerly did) in parts of NE India, but the two are ecologically separated. Monotypic.

The genus Paradoxornis has been moved from the family Sylviidae to Paradoxornithidae following Cai et al. (2019). Elsewhere, sometimes treated as conspecific with P. flavirostris (see related note/s). Proposed subspecies gongshanensis (W Yunnan, in S China) doubtfully valid. Treated as monotypic.

The genus Suthora has been moved from the family Sylviidae to Paradoxornithidae following Cai et al. (2019). Previously placed in Sinosuthora (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019). Formerly listed as Paradoxornis conspicillatus. Race rocki not very distinct (slightly thicker bill was greatly exaggerated in the text figure in type description), and supposedly paler plumage and lighter brown head not discernible on museum specimens examined; species may be better treated as monotypic. Two subspecies tentatively recognized.

The genus Suthora has been moved from the family Sylviidae to Paradoxornithidae following Cai et al. (2019). Suthora fulvifrons (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Paradoxornis fulvifrons.
Birds reported from W Arunachal Pradesh, in NE India, included in nominate, but may belong with subspecies chayulensis. Four subspecies recognized.

The genus Suthora has been moved from the family Sylviidae to Paradoxornithidae following Cai et al. (2019). Previously placed in Neosuthora (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019). Formerly it had been listed as Paradoxornis davidianus.

Racial identity of birds in extreme N Laos and extreme NW part of W Tonkin (N Vietnam) uncertain, but presumed to belong with thompsoni; likewise, birds in N (extreme E part) & C (NE part) Laos and neighbouring Vietnam (N Annam) presumed to belong with tonkinensis. Three subspecies currently recognized.

The genus Suthora has been moved from the family Sylviidae to Paradoxornithidae following Cai et al. (2019). Previously placed in Chleuasicus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019). Previously listed as Paradoxornis atrosuperciliaris. Racial identity of birds in W Arunachal Pradesh (W of R Dihang), in NE India, uncertain, presumed to belong with oatesi. Two subspecies recognized.
Rhabdornis inornatus and R. rabori (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as R. inornatus following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Previously placed in Sylvia (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019). Formerly also placed in genus Parisoma within family Timaliidae, but morphology, behaviour, vocalizations and mtDNA indicate that it belongs in present genus. Separation of subspecies not always possible owing to individual variation and presence of intermediates; further study required, and validity of some subspecies in need of review. Five subspecies recognized.

Previously placed in Sylvia but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019). Formerly also placed in genus Parisoma within family Timaliidae, but morphology, behaviour, vocalizations and mtDNA indicate better included in present genus. Identification of subspecies insufficiently understood, possibly only two merit recognition; further studies required in order to clarify true differences. Birds in S Ethiopia included in subspecies somalica, but may belong with marsabit. Three subspecies currently recognized.

Previously placed in Sylvia (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019). Formerly also placed in genus Parisoma within family Timaliidae, but morphology, behaviour, vocalizations and mtDNA indicate better included in present genus. Four subspecies recognized.

Previously placed in Sylvia (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019). Species name previously spelt erroneously as subcaerulea. Formerly placed in genus Parisoma within family Timaliidae, but morphology, behaviour, vocalizations and mtDNA indicate better included in present genus. Geographical differences in plumage coloration seem mainly clinal, and intermediates frequent; validity of some subspecies merits further study. Proposed subspecies ombuensis (from WC Namibia) synonymized with cinerascens, which intergrades rather widely with nominate and with ansorgei. Four subspecies recognized.

Previously placed in Sylvia (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019). Races form two groups, “leucomelaena group” N & E of Red Sea and “blanfordi group” W & S of Red Sea, these differing primarily in size and in degree of sexual dimorphism, but barely at all in voice; both groups exhibit clinal variation in upperpart coloration (becoming darker and less grey N–S), and W group also in amount of white on tail (increasing N–S). Birds from Yemen described as distincta, but fall into range of individual variation of nominate. Four subspecies recognized.
Eremopterix hova (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Mirafra hova.

Sometimes considered conspecific with M. africana, but the two are morphologically and vocally distinct, with no intermediate forms where their ranges meet in Kenya and N Tanzania. M. somalica perhaps also closely related to these two species, but relationship untested genetically (Alström et al. 2013a). We follow Donald & Alström (in prep) in synonymising the subspecies kathangorensis with the subspecies kidepoensis. Three subspecies recognized.
Mirafra africana and M. sharpii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as M. africana following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993).

Gillett’s Lark and Rusty Lark were previously included in Mirafra (del Hoyo & Collar 2016). Recent (as yet unpublished) genetic work supports previous assertions that their slender, pipit-like shape, lack of white outertail, proclivity for perching in trees and (in the case of Gillett’s Lark, as the song of Rusty Lark is unknown) simple song structure all clearly place them in Calendulauda. Close relationship with C. gilletti suggested by some authors, but no data on genetics for either species; Calendulauda poecilosterna (which has been sampled molecularly) suggested as third member of same grouping. We follow Donald & Alström (in prep) in synonymising the subspecies nigriticola with the nominate. Two subspecies recognized.

Formerly placed in Mirafra, but genetic data situate it in Calendulauda. Geographical variation in plumage tone, darkest and richest in S; birds from extreme N of range (SE Sudan E to S Somalia) previously treated as subspecies australoabyssinica and others from rest of range (except N & E Kenya) as massaica, but differences minimal. Monotypic.
Calendulauda sabota (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Mirafra sabota.
Calendulauda albescens (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Certhilauda albescens.
Ammomanopsis grayi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Ammomanes grayi.

Calandrella rufescens, including heinei group (AERC TAC [2003]; Cramp et al. [1977-1994]; Dowsett and Forbes-Watson [1993]; Sibley and Monroe [1990, 1993]) and C. cheleensis (Sibley & Monroe [1990, 1993]) previously lumped into Alaudala rufescens (Hoyo and Collar 2016). However, Ghorbani et al. (2020) and Alström et al. (2021) used an integrative approach to assess taxonomic limits within the Lesser Short-toed Lark Alaudala rufescens complex, combining data on genetics, morphology, songs, behaviour and bioclimatic preferences. Three clades emerge with strong support for species-level recognition. These are the western Mediterranean Short-toed Lark A. rufescens, a central Turkestan Short-toed Lark A. heinei, and an eastern Asian Short-toed Lark A. cheleensis. Birds from Transbaikalia named as subspecies obscura, but indistinguishable from cheleensis; others from Tuva Republic and NW Mongolia recognised as tuvinica. Forms tangutica, seebohmi, beicki and stegmanni are treated as synonyms of kukunoorensis after Donald and Alström (in prep.). In the past, species sometimes listed under older name pispoletta, but precise identity of this name is uncertain. Four subspecies currently recognised.
Spizocorys starki (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Eremalauda starki.

Eremalauda dunni and E. eremodites (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as E. dunni following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Spizocorys fremantlii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Pseudalaemon fremantlii.
Dicaeum melanozanthum (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as D. melanoxanthum following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Dicaeum concolor and D. minullum (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as D. concolor following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Dicaeum erythrothorax and D. schistaceiceps (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as D. erythrothorax following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Dicaeum ignipectus, D. cambodianum, D. beccarii and D. luzoniense (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as D. ignipectus following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Dicaeum hirundinaceum, D. ignicolle and D. keiense (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as D. hirundinaceum following Christidis & Boles (2008); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Deleornis fraseri and D. axillaris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped and placed in the genus Anthreptes as A. fraseri following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993).
Anthreptes malacensis and A. griseigularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. malacensis following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Chalcoparia singalensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Anthreptes following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Anthreptes aurantius (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as A. aurantium following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Hedydipna collaris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Anthreptes following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Hedydipna metallica (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Anthreptes and listed as A. metallicus following AERC TAC (2003); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Molecular research by Campillo et al. (2018) established that the anomalous Purple-naped Sunbird (formerly Hypogramma hypogrammica) is sister to all members of the genus Arachnothera (to which it was transferred, following an earlier molecular paper, in the Checklist under the name Purple-naped Spiderhunter, A. hypogrammica (del Hoyo and Collar 2016).

It would still be legitimate to extend Arachnothera to cover the species, but given its distinctiveness (metallic plumage, unique tongue structure) Campillo et al. favoured its treatment in a separate genus, for which they continue to use Hypogramma. However, the Checklist (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) pointed out that Hypogramma is preoccupied and that an alternative generic name, Kurochkinegramma (Kashin,1978), had been proposed. This name is accepted here, with the English name reverting to Purple-naped Sunbird.

Previously the taxon was placed in the genus Hypogramma and listed as H. hypogrammicum following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Cinnyris batesi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Nectarinia following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Anthobaphes violacea (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Nectarinia following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Chalcomitra rubescens (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Nectarinia following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Leptocoma calcostetha (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Nectarinia following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Cinnyris jugularis and C. idenburgi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously placed in the genus Nectarinia and lumped as N. jugularis following Christidis & Boles (2008); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Cinnyris buettikoferi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Nectarinia following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Cinnyris solaris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Nectarinia following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Cinnyris sovimanga (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Nectarinia following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Cinnyris humbloti (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Nectarinia following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Cinnyris comorensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Nectarinia following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Cinnyris oustaleti (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Nectarinia following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Cinnyris osea (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Nectarinia following AERC TAC (2003); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Cinnyris habessinicus and C. idenburgi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously placed in the genus Nectarinia and lumped as N. habessinica following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Cinnyris lotenius (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Nectarinia and listed as N. lotenia following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Cinnyris manoensis and C. gertrudis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously placed in the genus Nectarinia and lumped as N. manoensis following Bowie et al. (2004), BirdLife Taxonomic Working Group.

Cinnyris pembae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Nectarinia following Archer and Turner (1993).

Cinnyris notatus, C. moebii and C. voeltzkowi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously placed in the genus Nectarinia and lumped as N. notata following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
