Padda fuscata (Handbook of the Birds of the World and Birdlife International 2022) was recently listed as Lonchura fuscata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016), but the distinctiveness of this and P. oryzivora has been demonstrated genetically (Olsson and Alström 2020) and they are returned to the genus in which they were previously placed following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Often treated as a subspecies of A. melanura of mainland New Zealand and other islands, but differed in larger size of male, greater extent of blue on the head, less yellow in plumage overall and no yellow flank patch, and in having a yellow, not a dark, eye. Monotypic.

Poodytes rufescens (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Bowdleria rufescens. Usually considered a subspecies of P. punctatus, but sometimes treated as separate species (perhaps more closely related to Fijian Cincloramphus rufus). Differed from P. punctatus in its white vs brown-streaked grey chin to lower belly (4); strong rufescent tone of upperparts, wings, tail and flanks (2); bolder, blacker streaks on upperparts and flanks (2); and osteological features (Olson 1990b). Close in size to P. caudatus, which was previously also treated as a subspecies of P. punctatus. Monotypic.
Cercomacroides laeta (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Cercomacra laeta.
Knipolegus aterrimus and K. heterogyna (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as K. aterrimus following Stotz et al. (1996).

Setophaga delicata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Dendroica following AOU (1998 & supplements). Formerly considered conspecific with S. adelaidae and S. subita, but the three have recently been shown to have a level of genetic differentiation similar to that of some continental American species. Monotypic.

Previously placed in Trichastoma (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to this genus following Cai et al. (2019). Previously considered conspecific with P. buettikoferi.
Subspecies garoense previously and erroneously listed under junior synonym assamense; however, these names are subjective synonyms and two different taxa may indeed be separable in this region (Dickinson & Cibois 2010, Rasmussen & Anderton 2012). Five subspecies currently recognized.

Previously placed in Trichastoma (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to this genus following Cai et al. (2019). Previously treated as conspecific with P. tickelli; precise relationships to congeners require elucidation. Monotypic.

Previously treated as Garrulax galbanus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cibois et al. (2018). Very closely related to, and until recently treated as conspecific with, P. courtoisi, but since separation of latter (Collar 2006) present species found also to possess a blue panel on ear-coverts (Wilkinson & He 2010) and “very distinct differences” in song (Edwards et al. 2016). Monotypic.

Previously treated as Garrulax ruficeps (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cibois et al. (2018). Closely related to and previously treated as conspecific with P. albogularis. Monotypic.

Dasycrotapha pygmaea (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Stachyris pygmaea.
Schoeniparus klossi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Alcippe klossi.

The genus Fulvetta has been moved from the family Sylviidae to Paradoxornithidae following Cai et al. (2019). Fulvetta formosana (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Alcippe formosana. Formerly treated as conspecific with F. cinereiceps and F. manipurensis. Monotypic.

Following Cai et al. (2019), all members of genus Alcippe now moved to their own family Alcippeidae. Formerly treated as conspecific with A. peracensis; split supported by recent molecular work (Moyle et al. 2012). Subspecies eremita poorly differentiated, and perhaps not worthy of recognition. Two subspecies recognized.

Suiriri suiriri (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) and the previously named S. affinis remain lumped following SACC (2005), however the type of S. s. affinis has been shown to refer to the form subsequently described as Chapada Flycatcher (previously S. islerorum), hence the latter receives the name S. affinis and the subspecies formerly described as S. s. affinis takes the new name S. s. burmeisteri Kirwan 2014.
Batis mixta and B. reichenowi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as B. mixta following Fjeldså et al. (2006).
Locustella seebohmi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Bradypterus seebohmi.

Previously treated as Garrulax poecilorhynchus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cibois et al. (2018).  See comments under P. caerulatus. Until recently, present species included with P. berthemyi. Monotypic.
Stelgidopteryx serripennis and S. ridgwayi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as S. serripennis following AOU (1998 & supplements) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Dasycrotapha plateni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Stachyris plateni.
Mixornis gularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Macronous gularis.
Schoeniparus castaneceps (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Alcippe castaneceps.

The genus Fulvetta has been moved from the family Sylviidae to Paradoxornithidae following Cai et al. (2019). Fulvetta cinereiceps (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Alcippe cinereiceps. Formerly treated as conspecific with F. cinereiceps and F. formosana. Two subspecies recognized.
Following Cai et al. (2019), all members of genus Alcippe now moved to their own family Alcippeidae. Formerly treated as conspecific with A. grotei. Two subspecies recognized.
Previously placed in Yuhina, but moved to Staphida following Cai et al. (2019). Formerly treated as conspecific with S. torqueola. Four subspecies recognized.

The genus Paradoxornis has been moved from the family Sylviidae to Paradoxornithidae following Cai et al. (2019). Previously placed in Psittiparus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019): it had been placed in Paradoxornis prior to that change.

Formerly considered conspecific with P. margaritae. Six subspecies recognized.
Myrmelastes saturatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Schistocichla saturata.
Horornis brunnescens (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Cettia brunnescens.
Cinnyris fuelleborni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Nectarinia following Bowie et al. (2004).

Usually considered conspecific with small-billed subspecies (nominate and fraseri) of N. acunhae of Inaccessible I, but see related note/s. Cytochrome b sequence of present species appears identical to that of N. wilkinsi, but the two are highly distinct morphologically and behave as separate species, with separate vocal systems and no evidence of hybridization between them; treatment of present species as subspecies of N. acunhae (Dickinson and Christidis 2014) incompatible with genetic evidence of independent evolution on each island. Monotypic.

Trochalopteron fairbanki, T. meridionale, T. jerdoni and T. cachinnans have been moved to the new genus Montecincla after they were found to be sister to a clade composed of Heterophasia, Minla, Actinodura, Leiothrix, Liocichla and Crocias (Robin et al. 2017). They have also received new common names, and are listed as Palani Chilappan Montecincla fairbanki, Ashambu Chilappan M. meridionalis, Banasura Chilappan M. jerdoni and Nilgiri Chilappan M. cachinnans.

T. fairbanki and T. meridionale (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Strophocincla fairbanki following Rasmussen and Anderton (2005).

Myiomela albiventris and M. major have been moved to the new genus Sholicola after they were found to be sister to a newly uncovered clade composed of several genera of mainly Asian blue-flycatchers (Robin et al. 2017). They have also received new common names, and are listed as White-bellied Sholakili Sholicola albiventris and Nilgiri Sholakili S. major.

The genus Fulvetta has been moved from the family Sylviidae to Paradoxornithidae following Cai et al. (2019). Fulvetta ruficapilla (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Alcippe ruficapilla. Formerly treated as conspecific with F. danisi.
Birds recorded in S China (Yunnan and Guizhou) probably belong in present species on basis of range, but not yet compared with type of F. danisi. Two subspecies recognized.
Erythrogenys erythrocnemis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Pomatorhinus erythrocnemis.

Bare-faced Bulbul has been shown not to be in the genus Pycnonotus via genetic analysis, which places it sister to Spizixos but sufficiently differentiated to warrant a novel genus, named Nok (Fuchs et al. 2018). This treatment is accepted by the BirdLife Taxonomic Working Group, which recognises Nok hualon (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2019).

Cinnyris mediocris and C. usambaricus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously placed in the genus Nectarinia and lumped as N. mediocris following Bowie et al. (2004), BirdLife Taxonomic Working Group.

Nominate subspecies and fraseri formerly considered conspecific with N. questi of Nightingale I, but genetic evidence suggests independent evolution on each island. Subspecies of present species breed assortatively in coastal habitats, where large-billed dunnei and small-billed, drab nominate subspecies behave as distinct species (distinct songs, and territorial behaviour focused primarily on members of own subspecies); in contrast, all three subspecies interbreed in ecotone between Blechnum heath and Phylica woodland on the island’s plateau. Three subspecies recognized.
Myrmelastes humaythae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Schistocichla humaythae.
Myrmelastes brunneiceps (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Schistocichla brunneiceps.
Myrmelastes rufifacies (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Schistocichla rufifacies.
Microspingus lateralis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Poospiza following SACC (2005 & updates).

Dicrurus hottentottus and D. striatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as D. hottentottus following a previous split of D. mengai from D. hottentottus, acknowledged by Rocamora & Yeatman-Berthelot (2009).
Scytalopus opacus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) previously listed as Scytalopus opaca.

Hydrornis guajanus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Pitta guajana and had previously been split into P. guajana, P. irena and P. schwaneri, by the BirdLife Taxonomic Working Group on the basis of many strong plumage differences, some morphometric differences in guajana, and modest vocal differences, as noted by Rheindt & Eaton (2010).

Hydrornis schwaneri (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Pitta schwaneri, following a split of P. guajana into P. guajana, P. irena and P. schwaneri, by the BirdLife Taxonomic Working Group on the basis of many strong plumage differences, some morphometric differences in guajana, and modest vocal differences, as noted by Rheindt & Eaton (2010).
Previously placed in Yuhina, but moved to Staphida following Cai et al. (2019). See Y. castaniceps. Formerly treated as conspecific with Y. castaniceps. Monotypic.
Pitta maxima and P. morotaiensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. maxima following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

The genus Rhopophilus has been moved from the family Sylviidae to Paradoxornithidae following Cai et al. (2019).

R. albosuperciliaris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was considered conspecific with R. pekinensis following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993), but review (Leader et al. 2013) revealed that it differs in its dark brown vs whitish irides (3); more weakly streaked crown (2); flanks weakly streaked apricot-buff on off-white vs boldly streaked rufous on white (3); greyer cast to crown and tail (ns1); larger size (effect size for wing 2.97; score 2); differences in voice (allowed 3 (Leader et al. 2013)); drier, more desert-like habitat (1). Monotypic.

As part of their overhaul of the Locustellidae (see below) Alström et al. (2018) introduced the generic name Helopsaltes to cover the monophyletic group of Locustella warbler species ochotensis, pleskei, certhiola, pryeri, fasciolata and amnicola (del Hoyo and Collar 2016). They found no morphological diagnostic characters, but identified a clear difference in voice. 

Before this genus change, Locustella fasciolata and L. amnicola (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously treated as a single species, L. fasciolata, following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993). Although described as a species, often treated as a subspecies of H. fasciolata, but genetic distinctiveness rather strong (Alström et al. 2011, Drovetski et al. 2004, Drovetski et al. 2015); and while it differs only subtly in morphology, with summer birds having browner, less olive-green upperparts (1), brown vs grey ear-coverts (ns1), reduced or no grey on dull olive-buff breast and flanks (1), warm fulvous-brown vs pale brown lower flanks to vent (1) and slightly shorter wing and tarsus (allow 1), vocally fairly distinctive, with slower (2), longer (2) song phrases (Boesman 2016). However, review of characters suggests distinctiveness of plumage characters not always consistent (Neufeldt & Netschajew 1977, Neufeldt & Netschajew 1978), and trend in H. fasciolata in NE China towards characters associated with present species (Kennerley & Pearson 2010) indicates more work is needed to confirm this split. Monotypic.

Turdus naumanni and T. eunomus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. naumanni following AERC TAC (2003), AOU (1998 & supplements), Cramp et al. (1977-1994) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Previously listed as Garrulax cinereiceps (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cibois et al. (2018). Prior to this treated as conspecific with I. cineraceus as G. cineraceus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993). Differs from I. cineraceus in its dull grey-brown vs black crown (3); warmer, darker upperparts (1); dull chestnut supercilium and ear-coverts with no postocular black streak (3); and pale vinous vs buffy-whitish throat, submoustachial area and breast (ns1). Width of zone of hybridization with strenuus unknown (score at least 1), and taxonomic status of SC & SW Sichuan populations (and perhaps elsewhere) awaiting clarification (presumed here to belong with present species). Monotypic.

Previously treated as Garrulax monachus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cibois et al. (2018). Until recently considered conspecific with P. chinensis as G. chinensis following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993), but split prompted by molecular evidence (Wu et al. 2012) although comparisons failed to include P. c. germaini, the closest in plumage colour; differs from latter in its black vs white ear-coverts, lower face and submoustachial area (4); all-darkish-brown underparts with no hint of mid-grey on belly (1); notably smaller size (effect size for male wings –2.82, score 2). Monotypic.

Trochalopteron fairbanki, T. meridionale, T. jerdoni and T. cachinnans have been moved to the new genus Montecincla after they were found to be sister to a clade composed of Heterophasia, Minla, Actinodura, Leiothrix, Liocichla and Crocias (Robin et al. 2017). They have also received new common names, and are listed as Palani Chilappan Montecincla fairbanki, Ashambu Chilappan M. meridionalis, Banasura Chilappan M. jerdoni and Nilgiri Chilappan M. cachinnans.

T. fairbanki and T. meridionale (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Strophocincla fairbanki following Rasmussen and Anderton (2005).

Trochalopteron fairbanki, T. meridionale, T. jerdoni and T. cachinnans have been moved to the new genus Montecincla after they were found to be sister to a clade composed of Heterophasia, Minla, Actinodura, Leiothrix, Liocichla and Crocias (Robin et al. 2017). They have also received new common names, and are listed as Palani Chilappan Montecincla fairbanki, Ashambu Chilappan M. meridionalis, Banasura Chilappan M. jerdoni and Nilgiri Chilappan M. cachinnans.

A comprehensive phylogenetic analysis of bulbuls (Shakya and Sheldon 2017) recommends that the five species previously lumped as Pycnonotus melanicterus be moved into the genus Rubigula (Blyth, 1845), consequently R. melanictera, R. gularis, R. flaviventris, R. dispar and R. montis (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2019) are accepted.

Pycnonotus melanicterus, P. gularis, P. flaviventris, P. dispar and P. montis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. melanicterus following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Atlapetes leucopterus and A. paynteri (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. leucopterus following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

A comprehensive phylogenetic analysis of bulbuls (Shakya and Sheldon 2017) recommends that the five species previously lumped as Pycnonotus melanicterus be moved into the genus Rubigula (Blyth, 1845), consequently R. melanictera, R. gularis, R. flaviventris, R. dispar and R. montis (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2019) are accepted.

Pycnonotus melanicterus, P. gularis, P. flaviventris, P. dispar and P. montis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. melanicterus following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

A comprehensive phylogenetic analysis of bulbuls (Shakya and Sheldon 2017) recommends that the five species previously lumped as Pycnonotus melanicterus be moved into the genus Rubigula (Blyth, 1845), consequently R. melanictera, R. gularis, R. flaviventris, R. dispar and R. montis (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2019) are accepted.

Pycnonotus melanicterus, P. gularis, P. flaviventris, P. dispar and P. montis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. melanicterus following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Cyanolyca armillata and C. quindiuna (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. armillata following SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Pycnonotus flavescens and P. leucops (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. flavescens following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Cyanoderma erythropterum and C. bicolor (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Stachyris erythroptera following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Calandrella brachydactyla and C. dukhunensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped into C. brachydactyla following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Until recently considered conspecific with C. brachydactyla, but molecular evidence places it as sister to C. acutirostris (Alström et al. 2013); this finding accepted here, and present species appears to differ in its longer wings (allow 1); deeper or shorter bill (allow 1); fulvous-washed breastband (1); heavier, darker streaking on upperparts (1); and melodious song distantly recalling Lullula arborea (Schäfer 1938) (allow 3). Monotypic.
Ptyonoprogne fuligula and P. rufigula (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Hirundo fuligula following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Acridotheres burmannicus and A. leucocpehalus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Sturnus burmannicus following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Copsychus saularis and C. mindanensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. saularis following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Previously listed as Kittacincla superciliaris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to Copsychus on the basis of unpublished genetic data (Per Alström, in litt via WGAC) that support a broad Copsychus. Kittacincla luzoniensis and K. superciliaris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Copsychus luzoniensis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993). Until recently considered conspecific with C. luzoniensis, but differs genetically (Lim et al. 2010, Sánchez-González et al. 2015) and by its all-dark vs rufous rump (3); all-dark wings and tail (lacking white wing patch and bold tail tips) (3); whiter underparts (1); shorter tail (effect size –4.75, score 2); and longer legs (effect size 2.71, score 2) (Collar 2011). Monotypic.

Tarsiger cyanurus and T. rufilatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. cyanurus following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 & supplements); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Unpublished genetic data (Frank Rheindt in litt. via WGAC) clearly place all Cyornis east of Wallace’s Line within Eumyias. To prevent the common names ‘jungle-flycatcher’ or ‘blue-flycatcher’ being applied to species in two different genera, these species are given the common name ‘warbling-flycatcher’. Cyornis oscillans and C. stresemanni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Rhinomyias oscillans following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993). Until recently considered conspecific with E. oscillans, but differs in its grey-tinged buff vs darker and purer grey head sides and underparts (2); whiter belly (ns at least 1); white vs buffy-rufous undertail-coverts (2); brighter brown above (1); larger size overall, with distinctly longer bill (on published evidence mean 18.4 mm (Vaurie 1952) vs 15.7 (Vaurie 1952) or 15.2 (Mees 2006) in males; sample size small but supported by available photographs and our inspection of museum material; allow 2); lowland vs montane habitat (Mees 2006) (requires confirmation; ns); possibly more frugivorous diet (Vaurie 1952) (ns); and apparently different song (Eaton et al. 2016). Monotypic.
Cyornis herioti and C. camarienensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. herioti following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Cyornis tickelliae and C. sumatrensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. tickelliae following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Cyornis rubeculoides and C. glaucicomans (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. rubeculoides following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Zoothera mollissima and Z. griseiceps (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Z. mollissima following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993), which included the formerly overlooked Z. salimali (Alström et al. 2016)

Anthus similis and A. nyassae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. similis following AERC TAC (2003); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993). Anthus longicaudatus is no longer recognised as a species, following del Hoyo and Collar (2016) ; available material in museums is an amalgam of specimens of A. vaalensis and A. similis.
Zoothera talaseae and Z. atrigena (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Z. talaseae following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Turdus olivaceus, T. abyssinicus, T. roehli and T. smithi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. olivaceus following Collar and Stuart (1985) and Collar et al. (1994).
Turdus olivaceus, T. abyssinicus, T. roehli and T. smithi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. olivaceus following Collar and Stuart (1985) and Collar et al. (1994).
Turdus chiguanco and T. anthracinus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. chiguanco following SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Turdus ignobilis, T. debilis and T. arthuri (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. ignobilis following SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Turdus ignobilis, T. debilis and T. arthuri (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. ignobilis following SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

Turdus plumbeus, T. rubripes and T. ardosiaceus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. plumbeus following AOU (1998 & supplements), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

Turdus plumbeus, T. rubripes and T. ardosiaceus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. plumbeus following AOU (1998 & supplements), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

Turdus merula, T. simillimus, T. maximus and T. mandarinus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. merula following AERC TAC (2003), AOU (1998 & supplements), Christidis & Boles (2008), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Turbott (1990).
Turdus poliocephalus and T. niveiceos (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. poliocephalus following Christidis & Boles (2008) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Larvivora ruficeps (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Luscinia following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Symposiachrus sacerdotum (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Monarcha sacerdotum.
Sarcophanops samarensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Eurylaimus samarensis.

All members of genus Suthora now moved to the family Paradoxornithidae following Cai et al. (2019). Previously placed in Sinosuthora (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) and prior to that listed in Paradoxornis, but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019). Two subspecies recognized.
Symposiachrus everetti (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Monarcha everetti.
Machlolophus nuchalis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus nuchalis.

Previously placed in genus Rimator (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019). Formerly treated as conspecific with N. malacoptila and N. albostriata following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993). Monotypic.
Trochalopteron yersini (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Garrulax yersini.
Hydrornis baudii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Pitta baudii.
Cercomacroides serva (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Cercomacra serva.
Drymotoxeres pucheranii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Drymotoxeres pucherani.
Cyornis umbratilis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Rhinomyias umbratilis.
Laniellus albonotatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Crocias albonotatus.

Previously listed as Crateroscelis murina (del Hoyo and Collar 2016), but moved to current genus following Norman et al. (2018). Race fumosa perhaps indistinguishable from capitalis (Beehler and Pratt 2016). Sclater’s murina published in May, Gray’s monacha in Jul (Peterson 1999). Five subspecies recognized.
Dicrurus annectens (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Dicrurus annectans.
Cinclus schulzii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as C. schulzi.
Cyornis pallidipes (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Cyornis pallipes.
Sheppardia polioptera (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Cossypha polioptera.

Previously listed as Hodgsonius phaenicuroides (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but genetic analyses of Sangster et al. (2010) show both phaenicuroides and svecica in a monophyletic position with Luscinia luscinia and Luscinia megarhynchos. Two subspecies recognized.
Ptyonoprogne obsoleta (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Hirundo obsoleta.
Cecropis abyssinica (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Hirundo abyssinica.
Arizelocichla masukuensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Andropadus masukuensis.
Iole viridescens (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as I. virescens.
Horornis diphone (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Cettia diphone.
Horornis fortipes (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Cettia fortipes.
Locustella major (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Bradypterus major.

As part of their overhaul of the Locustellidae (see below) Alström et al. (2018) introduced the generic name Helopsaltes to cover the monophyletic group of Locustella warbler species ochotensis, pleskei, certhiola, pryeri, fasciolata and amnicola (del Hoyo and Collar 2016). They found no morphological diagnostic characters, but identified a clear difference in voice.Has been considered conspecific with either or both of H. certhiola and H. ochotensis, but differs in voice, morphology and ecology. Molecular data reveal intraspecific structure among populations assigned to present species, while simultaneously suggesting that H. ochotensis shows remarkably little divergence (Drovetski et al. 2004, Drovetski et al. 2015). Monotypic.
Iduna caligata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Hippolais caligata.
Phyllergates cucullatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Orthotomus cucullatus.
Previously placed in monotypic Chaetornis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to Schoenicola following Alström et al. (2018). Monotypic.

Previously listed as Garrulax ocellatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cibois et al. (2018). See comments under I. maxima. Subspecies maculipectus previously listed under older name similis; with inclusion of present species and Trochalopteron variegatum simile in genus Garrulax, name similis became preoccupied, and was replaced by maculipectus; this made the name similis permanently invalid for the taxon now known as maculipectus, even though herein the two forms are not treated as congeneric. Four subspecies recognized.
Trochalopteron austeni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Garrulax austeni.
Trochalopteron elliotii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Garrulax elliotii.
Trochalopteron henrici (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Garrulax henrici.

The genus Lioparus has been moved from the family Sylviidae to Paradoxornithidae following Cai et al. (2019). Lioparus chrysotis was previously listed as Alcippe chrysotis.
Races form three groups: “chrysotis group”, with greyish crown and throat and no or vestigial pale coronal stripe; “swinhoii group”, with bold white coronal stripe and blackish crown and throat; and single-taxon “robsoni group”, with yellow throat, yellow-tinged area around eye, olive-tinged crown and ear-coverts, more strongly orange wingpanel formed by edges of secondaries, and possibly smaller size. Study to check species limits needed, although vocal differences not apparent. Birds reported from C Yunnan (N Ailao Shan), in S China, have not been assigned to subspecies. Six subspecies recognized.
Schoeniparus brunneus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Alcippe brunnea.

Following Cai et al. (2019), all members of genus Alcippe now moved to their own family Alcippeidae. Several subspecies proposed, but only eriphaea (Borneo) currently accepted, primarily on basis of vocal differences (Eaton et al. 2016). Two subspecies recognized.

Following Cai et al. (2019), all members of genus Alcippe now moved to their own family Alcippeidae. Has elsewhere been considered conspecific with A. pyrrhoptera. Subspecies in peninsular India (nominate and brucei), with somewhat different songs from those of other subspecies (Boesman 2016), considered possibly to represent a separate species, but plumage distinctions weak. Eight subspecies recognized.
Following Cai et al. (2019), all members of genus Alcippe now moved to their own family Alcippeidae. Has elsewhere been treated as a subspecies of A. poioicephala. Monotypic.
Laniellus langbianis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Crocias langbianis.
Alaudala somalica (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Calandrella somalica.

Spinus spinus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Carduelis following AERC TAC (2003), AOU (1998 and supplements), Cramp et al. (1977–1994), and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Linaria flavirostris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Carduelis following AERC TAC (2003); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Cercomacroides parkeri (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Cercomacra parkeri.
Previously listed as Garrulax konkakinhensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cibois et al. (2018). Monotypic.
Lagonosticta rubricata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously split as L. rubricata and L. landanae following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Locustella mandelli (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Bradypterus mandelli.

Previously placed in Sylvia but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019). Until recently considered conspecific with C. nana (AERC TAC 2003, Cramp et al. 1977-1994, Dowsett and Forbes-Watson 1993, Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993), but differs in its sandier-rufous (less greyish) crown to back (2); greatly reduced blackish centres of inner tertials and central rectrices (2); whiter underparts (1); slightly longer bill (effect size 1.58, score 1); but slightly shorter wing, indicating non-migratory habit (effect size –1.48, score 1). Claims of “very different” voices (Shirihai et al. 2001) (apparently responsible for near-universal acceptance of split) could not, however, be confirmed in independent analysis of available recordings (Boesman 2016), although low level of divergence may exist. Form described as ticehursti on basis of single specimen from S Morocco (near Ouarzazate), and treated either as separate species or as subspecies of C. deserticola, is probably aberrant individual of subspecies maroccana of latter (which it resembles in general structure and in tail and tertial patterns), or hybrid between it and present species (which it resembles in having pale sandy-brown upperparts). Monotypic.
Trochalopteron chrysopterum (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Garrulax chrysopterus.

The genus Fulvetta has been moved from the family Sylviidae to Paradoxornithidae following Cai et al. (2019). Fulvetta danisi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Alcippe danisi. Formerly treated as conspecific with F. ruficapilla (see related note/s). Two subspecies recognized.

The genus Fulvetta has been moved from the family Sylviidae to Paradoxornithidae following Cai et al. (2019). Fulvetta manipurensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Alcippe manipurensis. Formerly treated as conspecific with F. cinereiceps and F. formosana. Two subspecies recognized.
Trochalopteron erythrocephalum (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Garrulax erythrocephalus.
Horornis acanthizoides (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Cettia acanthizoides.

Cercomacroides nigrescens and C. fuscicauda (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Cercomacra nigrescens following SACC (2005 and updates), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Niltava vivida and N. oatesi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as N. vivida following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Cyanoptila cyanomelana and C. cumatilis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. cyanomelana following Christidis and Boles (2008) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Eumyias indigo and E. ruficrissa (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as E. indigo following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Unpublished genetic data (Frank Rheindt in litt. via WGAC) clearly place all Cyornis east of Wallace’s Line within Eumyias. To prevent the common names ‘jungle-flycatcher’ or ‘blue-flycatcher’ being applied to species in two different genera, these species are given the common name ‘warbling-flycatcher’. Cyornis oscillans and C. stresemanni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Rhinomyias oscillans following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993). Usually considered conspecific with E. stresemanni (see related note/s). Affinity of birds on Sumbawa unclear; tentatively included here. Monotypic.
Cyornis herioti and C. camarienensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. herioti following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Cyornis tickelliae and C. sumatrensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. tickelliae following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Crithagra reichardi and C. striatipectus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously placed in the genus Serinus and lumped as S. reichardi following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Cyornis rubeculoides and C. glaucicomans (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. rubeculoides following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Dessonornis anomalus, D. macclounii and D. mbuluensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Cossypha anomala following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Dessonornis anomalus, D. macclounii and D. mbuluensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Cossypha anomala following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Sheppardia bocagei and S. poensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as S. bocagei following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993).
Larvivora akahige and L. tanensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously placed in the genus Erithacus and lumped as E. akahige following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Trochalopteron fairbanki, T. meridionale, T. jerdoni and T. cachinnans have been moved to the new genus Montecincla after they were found to be sister to a clade composed of Heterophasia, Minla, Actinodura, Leiothrix, Liocichla and Crocias (Robin et al. 2017). They have also received new common names, and are listed as Palani Chilappan Montecincla fairbanki, Ashambu Chilappan M. meridionalis, Banasura Chilappan M. jerdoni and Nilgiri Chilappan M. cachinnans.

Previously listed as Kittacincla luzoniensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to Copsychus on the basis of unpublished genetic data (Per Alström, in litt. via WGAC) that support a broad Copsychus. Kittacincla luzoniensis and K. superciliaris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Copsychus luzoniensis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993). Until recently considered conspecific with C. superciliaris. Subspecies parvimaculata only rather weakly differentiated from nominate; shemleyi poorly known, and validity has been questioned. Deep genetic divergence reported among populations ascribed to nominate subspecies from different parts of Luzon (Sánchez-González et al. 2015). Three subspecies currently recognized.

The genus Paradoxornis has been moved from the family Sylviidae to Paradoxornithidae following Cai et al. (2019). 
Has been suggested that subspecies polivanovi merits species status, but considered by some authors to represent one end of a geographical cline (Yeung et al. 2011); Mongolian birds proposed as separate subspecies, mongolicus, but differences from polivanovi minimal (slightly purer grey mantle lacking dark streaks, slightly darker back, rump and breast sides, slightly smaller size) and may involve minor clinal variation; in both cases, separation was based largely on presumed “huge” gap between N & S forms, but several populations since found in intervening areas and likely that species will prove to have more continuous range. Populations of this species in coastal Tianjin Municipality (N & S Hebei) and coastal Liaoning, in E China, presumed to belong to nominate subspecies. Two subspecies currently recognized.

As part of their overhaul of the Locustellidae (see below) Alström et al. (2018) introduced the generic name Helopsaltes to cover the monophyletic group of Locustella warbler species ochotensis, pleskei, certhiola, pryeri, fasciolatus and amnicola (del Hoyo and Collar 2016, Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2022). They found no morphological diagnostic characters, but identified a clear difference in voice. Helopsaltes takes the masculine form, hence the previous listing as H. fasciolata was incorrect.

Before this genus change, Locustella fasciolata and L. amnicola (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously treated as a single species, L. fasciolata, following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993). Monotypic.

Eight species, Hypsipetes affinis, H. longirostris, H. mysticalis, H. harterti, H. aureus, H. platenae, H. chloris and H. lucasi have been moved from the genus Thapsinllas (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) following a comprehensive phylogeny of the bulbuls (Shakya and Sheldon 2017). All were previously lumped as Alophoixus affinis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Previously placed in Sylvia but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019). Formerly treated as a subspecies of C. sarda, but differs in its paler throat (1); paler belly and flanks (1); smaller size (effect size for wing based on published data (Shirihai et al. 2001) –3.5, score 2); somewhat different song (to which the other species does not respond; allow 2); clearly different contact calls (at least 2); and migratory pattern (1). Monotypic.

The genus Suthora has been moved from the family Sylviidae to Paradoxornithidae following Cai et al. (2019). Previously placed in Sinosuthora (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019). Until recently considered conspecific with S. ricketti as Paradoxornis brunneus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) (see related note). 
Elsewhere considered conspecific with S. webbiana (and S. alphonsiana) by some authors, but widely accepted treatment as separate species supported by differences in skeletal features of skull. Ranges of nominate and styani meet at S end of Dali Valley, at least; latter may be result of secondary intergradation, but museum specimens appear uniform in plumage characters, suggesting that it is a valid subspecies. Two subspecies recognized.

The genus Suthora has been moved from the family Sylviidae to Paradoxornithidae following Cai et al. (2019). Previously placed in Sinosuthora (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019). Until recently considered conspecific with S. brunnea as Paradoxornis brunneus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993), but differs genetically (Yeung et al. 2011) and in its creamy-white vs blackish iris (3); black eyering with whitish area immediately around it (2); paler head sides than crown, giving capped appearance (ns1); long narrow brown streaks on greyish-white chin to lower breast vs on pinkish-buff throat with plainer pinkish-buff breast (1); marginally paler belly (ns); darker chestnut crown to mantle, although this not apparent on all specimens (ns); more rasping calls (allow 1) (Wright et al. 2014). Monotypic.

Zosterops poliogastrus, Z. kaffensis, Z. kulalensis, Z. kikuyuensis, Z. silvanus, Z. eurycricotus, Z. mbuluensis and Z. winifredae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Z. poliogastrus following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Zosterops rendovae and Z. hamlini (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Z. rendovae following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Zosterops rendovae and Z. hamlini (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Z. rendovae following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Zosterops cinereus and Z. ponapensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Z. cinereus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Zosterops cinereus and Z. ponapensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Z. cinereus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Pomatorhinus ferruginosus and P. phayrei (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. ferruginosus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Mixornis flavicollis and M. prillwitzi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Macronous flavicollis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Illadopsis rufipennis and I. distans (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as I. rufipennis following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Pellorneum capistratum and P. nigrocapitatum (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. capistratum following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Previously placed in Turdoides (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019) - although this taxon was not included in that analysis, the frequent treatment of this taxon and A. striata as one species (as previously here, following Sibley and Monroe [1990, 1993]) suggests it also belongs in Argya.
Differs from A. striata in its vaguely scalloped vs vaguely streaked breast (2); black edges to primaries forming bold black panel on closed wing (3); stronger rufous tinge to lower underparts and buffy-rufous vs pale grey rump (2); parapatric distribution or very narrow zone of hybridization (assume latter; score 2) with A. s. malabarica in S of range. Monotypic.

Previously listed as Garrulax cineraceus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cibois et al. (2018). Prior to this treated as conspecific with I. cinereiceps as G. cineraceus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993). Taxonomic status of populations in SC & SW Sichuan (and perhaps elsewhere in this region) unclear; here presumed to belong with I. cinereiceps. Two subspecies currently recognized.

Previously treated as Garrulax chinensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cibois et al. (2018). Prior to this was considered conspecific with P. monachus as G. chinensis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993). Form “lugens” (from Indochina) is a dark morph of nominate subspecies. Four subspecies recognized.

Previously treated as Garrulax treacheri (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cibois et al. (2018). Until recently considered conspecific with P. mitratus as G. mitratus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993). Three subspecies recognized.

Previously treated as Garrulax woodi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cibois et al. (2018). Until recently considered conspecific with P. lanceolatus as Babax lanceolatus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993), with arguments for and against separation (Collar 2006, Rasmussen & Anderton 2005); split now accepted here based in part on new vocal analysis, present species differing in its bolder-patterned crown (2); black vs dark chestnut submoustachial stripe (1); fuller, darker-centred streaking on lower underparts (1); somewhat longer bill (allow 1) but slightly shorter tail (allow 1) (sample sizes small but pattern consistent for both sexes); “different” voice (as reported by multiple observers), tentatively assessed here on small available sample as involving a greater number of notes per song phrase (2) and more complex note shape (1) (Boesman 2016). Monotypic.
Phylloscopus intensior (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as P. davisoni.
Hypsipetes siquijorensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Ixos siquijorensis.
Kleinothraupis parodii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Hemispingus following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Loxops coccineus, L. ochraceus and L. wolstenholmei (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as L. coccineus following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Phoenicurus bicolor (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Rhyacornis following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Turdus eremita (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Nesocichla eremita.
Acrocephalus caffer, A. musae and A. longirostris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. caffer following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Zosterops conspicillatus and Z. saypani (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Z. conspicillatus following Slikas et al. (2000).
Sarcophanops steerii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Eurylaimus steerii.

As part of their overhaul of the Locustellidae (see below) Alström et al. (2018) introduced the generic name Helopsaltes to cover the monophyletic group of Locustella warbler species ochotensis, pleskei, certhiola, pryeri, fasciolata and amnicola (del Hoyo and Collar 2016). They found no morphological diagnostic characters, but identified a clear difference in voice. 
Previously L. pryeri (del Hoyo & Collar 2016) was placed in Megalurus, but morphological features (bill and foot structure, length of undertail-coverts, wing formula) and molecular data place it within Helopsaltes (Alström et al. 2018). Subspecies sinensis suggested as perhaps a separate species, but although it is whitish vs pale grey from throat to belly (1), with less extensive and paler rufous flanks (2) and paler upperparts (1), the voices are near-identical. Two subspecies recognized.
Epimachus fastosus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as E. fastuosus.
Fraseria tessmanni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Muscicapa tessmanni.
Sylvia nigricapillus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Lioptilus nigricapillus.
Rhipidura rufifrons, R. melanolaema and R. dryas (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as R. rufifrons following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Synallaxis hellmayri (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Gyalophylax hellmayri.
Malindangia mcgregori (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Coracina mcgregori.
Cinnyris ursulae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Nectarinia following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Foulehaio carunculatus, F. procerior and F. taviunensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as F. carunculatus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Jønsson et al. (2018) establish that Cerulean Paradise-flycatcher Eutrichomyias rowleyi, Drongo Fantail Chaetorhynchus papuensis, Natewa Silktail Lamprolia klinesmithi and Taveuni Silktail L. victoriae belong in a separate ancient family, Lamproliidae, sister to the Rhipiduridae. This finding is accepted here.

Lamprolia victoriae and L. klinesmithi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as L. victoriae following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Crithagra melanochroa (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Serinus and listed as S. melanochrous following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Previously listed as Kittacincla albiventris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to Copsychus on the basis of unpublished genetic data (Per Alström, in litt. via WGAC) that support a broad Copsychus. Kittacincla malabarica and K. albiventris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Copsychus malabaricus following AOU (1998 and supplements) and Collar (2004). Until recently considered conspecific with C. malabaricus, but differs in its black vs rufous lower breast (i.e. black extends much further down breast) (3); white vs rufous belly (3); shorter tail (Rasmussen and Anderton 2005) (allow 1); song phrases generally shorter with fewer notes (ns1), with lower mean minimum and lower maximum frequency (2) and always vs very rarely ending with low-frequency whistle (2) (Boesman 2016). Monotypic.
Hydrornis caeruleus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Pitta caerulea.
Pitta sordida, P. novaeguineae and P. rosenbergii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. sordida following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Myrmelastes leucostigma (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Schistocichla leucostigma.
Grallaria rufula and G. saltuensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as G. rufula following SACC (2005 and updates), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

Xiphorhynchus ocellatus, X. beauperthuysii and X. chunchotambo (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as X. ocellatus following SACC (2005 and updates), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Cranioleuca vulpina and C. dissita (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. vulpina following AOU (1998 and supplements) and SACC (2005 and updates).
Dendrocitta bayleii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as D. bayleyi.
Hirundinea ferruginea and H. bellicosa (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as H. ferruginea following SACC (2005 & updates).
Previously listed as Garrulax bieti (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cibois et al. (2018). Has elsewhere been treated as conspecific with I. lunulatus. Monotypic.

Gracupica contra and G. jalla (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Sturnus contra following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993). Differs from G. contra in its uniform whitish-yellow bill vs two-tone orange/whitish-yellow bill (3); large naked orange face patch vs orange eyering (2); bare reddish vs white feathered lores (2). Differs further from G. c. contra in its browner back (ns1); whiter underparts (ns1); and shorter tail (effect size -1.63, score 1); from G. c. superciliaris in its lack of white streaks on frontal crown (ns2); whiter underparts (ns1); and longer wing (effect size 2.45, score 2). Differs from G. floweri in its lack of white streaks on crown (3 consequently discounting score of 2 for lores); browner back (ns1); and shorter tail (effect size -2.56, score 2). Monotypic.
Melithreptus gularis and M. laetior (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as M. gularis following Christidis and Boles (1994, 2008).
Pachycephala simplex and P. griseiceps (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. simplex following Christidis & Boles (1994, 2008)
Pachycephala simplex and P. griseiceps (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. simplex following Christidis and Boles (1994, 2008).

The genus Paradoxornis has been moved from the family Sylviidae to Paradoxornithidae following Cai et al. (2019). 
Previously placed in Psittiparus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019).
Until recently (King and Robson 2008) considered conspecific with P. ruficeps following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993), but differs in its slightly darker upperparts (1); bright buff vs buff-stained white underparts (2); overall larger size (effect size for bill on published data (King and Robson 2008) 1.68, score 1); and song a rhythmic phrase ending with long drawn-out whistles at about 2–3 kHz vs a series of 4–6 descending whistles each about the same length and shape, typically in range 3–4.5 kHz, thus main differences being presence of long notes (3) and greater variety of notes (1).
Birds from N Laos and N Vietnam (E Tonkin) have been separated under name magnirostris, but differences appear too slight to merit taxonomic recognition. Monotypic.

The genus Paradoxornis has been moved from the family Sylviidae to Paradoxornithidae following Cai et al. (2019). Previously placed in Psittiparus but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019). Until recently (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) considered conspecific with P. bakeri as P. ruficeps following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) (see related note/s). Monotypic.
Psophocichla litsitsirupa and P. simensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. litsitsirupa following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Geokichla dumasi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Zoothera dumasi.
Foudia eminentissima, F. consobrina and F. aldabrana (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as F. eminentissima following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Rhipidura rufiventris, R. tenkatei, R. hoedti, R. bouruensis, R. obiensis, R. cinerea, R. assimilis, R. kordensis and R. isura (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as R. rufiventris following Christidis and Boles (2008) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Sittiparus varius, S. owstoni, S. olivaceus and S. castaneoventris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Parus varius following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Serpophaga subcristata and S. munda (SACC [2005 & updates]; Sibley & Monroe [1990, 1993]; Stotz et al. [1996]) have been lumped and split into S. subcristata and S. griseicapilla following del Hoyo and Collar 2016.
Chenorhamphus grayi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Malurus grayi.
Amytornis textilis and A. modestus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. textilis following Christidis & Boles (2008) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Melithreptus gularis and M. laetior (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as M. gularis following Christidis and Boles (1994, 2008).
Myzomela eques and M. cineracea (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as M. eques following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Myzomela obscura, M. simplex, M. rubrotincta and M. rubrobrunnea (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as M. obscura following Christidis & Boles (2008) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Myzomela chloroptera and M. batjanensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as M. chloroptera following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Previously listed as Sericornis papuensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Norman et al. (2018). Geographical variation poorly understood (Beehler and Pratt 2016); study needed. Three subspecies recognized.

Previously listed as Sericornis perspicillatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Norman et al. (2018). Form described as Sericornis nigroviridis (dark olive-green, with dull blackish-grey on head to breast and central belly, some grey tips on upper throat) based on single specimen from near Wau (SE New Guinea), believed to be almost certainly a melanistic individual of present species. Monotypic.
Previously listed as Sericornis arfakianus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Norman et al. (2018). Monotypic.
Acanthiza cinerea (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Gerygone cinerea.
Coracina striata, C. panayensis and C. dobsoni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. striata following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Poecile atricapillus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus atricapillus.
Poecile gambeli (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus gambeli.
Cyanistes caeruleus and C. teneriffae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Parus caeruleus following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Pachycephala pectoralis, P. par, P. mentalis, P. vitiensis, P. feminina, P. orioloides, P. fulvotincta and P. teysmanni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. pectoralis following Christidis & Boles (2008) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Pachycephala pectoralis, P. par, P. mentalis, P. vitiensis, P. feminina, P. orioloides, P. fulvotincta and P. teysmanni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. pectoralis following Christidis and Boles (2008) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Pachycephala pectoralis, P. par, P. mentalis, P. vitiensis, P. feminina, P. orioloides, P. fulvotincta and P. teysmanni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. pectoralis following Christidis & Boles (2008) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Machlolophus xanthogenys  (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus xanthogenys.
Melaniparus leucomelas and M. guineensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as M. leucomelas following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993).
Melaniparus leucomelas and M. guineensis (del Hoyo and Collar   2016) were previously lumped as M. leucomelas following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993).
Edolisoma coerulescens (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Coracina coerulescens.
Ramphocoris clotbey (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Rhamphocoris clotbey.

Gillett’s Lark and Rusty Lark were previously included in Mirafra (del Hoyo & Collar 2016). Recent (as yet unpublished) genetic work supports previous assertions that their slender, pipit-like shape, lack of white outertail, proclivity for perching in trees and (in the case of Gillett’s Lark, as the song of Rusty Lark is unknown) simple song structure all clearly place them in Calendulauda. Bears close resemblance to Calendulauda alopex intercedens. Form degodiensis, sometimes treated as a full species, differs only in its marginally smaller size (Collar et al. 2009), and perhaps better synonymized with nominate. Subspecies arorihensis intergrades with nominate in NW Somalia. Three subspecies recognized.
Alaudala raytal (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Calandrella raytal.
Eremomela pusilla and E. canescens (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumedp as E. pusilla following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993).
Apalis cinerea and A. alticola (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. cinerea following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993).

Cisticola galactotes, C. luapula, C. haematocephalus, C. lugubris and C. marginatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. galactotes following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Cisticola galactotes, C. luapula, C. haematocephalus, C. lugubris and C. marginatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. galactotes following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Cisticola galactotes, C. luapula, C. haematocephalus, C. lugubris and C. marginatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. galactotes following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Edolisoma montanum (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Coracina montana.
Edolisoma schisticeps (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Coracina schisticeps.

Edolisoma tenuirostre, E. insperatum, E. nesiotis, E. monacha, E. rostratum, E. meyerii, E. obiense, E. grayi, E. remotum and E. salomonis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Coracina tenuirostris following Christidis and Boles (2008) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Cisticola brunnescens and C. cinnamomeus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. brunnescens following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Cisticola brunnescens and C. cinnamomeus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. brunnescens following Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Lalage melanoptera (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Coracina melanoptera.
Prinia atrogularis, P. khasiana and P. superciliaris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. atrogularis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Prinia atrogularis, P. khasiana and P. superciliaris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. atrogularis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Artamus leucoryn (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Artamus leucorynchus.

Poodytes gramineus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Megalurus gramineus. 
Plumage pattern and biogeography suggest ancestral link with P. punctatus of New Zealand, and possibly also with Madagascar’s Amphilais (now Bradypterus) seebohmi. Validity of poorly known subspecies papuensis doubted in past, but separating characters have recently been confirmed and the taxon may merit further attention given its isolation (Beehler & Pratt 2016). Subspecies thomasi sometimes included in nominate (Johnstone & Storr 2004). Four subspecies recognised.

Originally described in Timaliidae and subsequently treated in various genera. Formerly placed within the unique genus Buettikoferella (del Hoyo and Collar 2016), but molecular analysis of Alström et al. (2018) places it within the current genus. Monotypic.
Xanthomixis zosterops (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Bernieria zosterops.

Delichon urbicum and D. lagopodum (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as D. urbicum following AERC TAC (2003), AOU (1998 & supplements), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Dyaphorophyia blissetti (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Platysteira blissetti.
Petrochelidon spilodera (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Hirundo spilodera.

Forest Swallow has been reassigned to a new genus, Atronanus, by de Silva et al. (2018) based on a combination of molecular genetic results and distinct morphological characters. The BirdLife Taxonomic Working Group accepts this treatment and recognises Atronanus fuliginosus (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2019). 

Previously, Petrochelidon fuliginosa (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was listed as Hirundo fuliginosa.
Bocagia minuta (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Tchagra minutus.

Laniarius aethiopicus, L. nigerrimus and L. sublacteus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as L. aethiopicus following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Carterornis chrysomela (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Monarcha chrysomela.
Terpsiphone cinnamomea and T. unirufa (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. cinnamomea following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Lanius excubitor, L. borealis and L. meridionalis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as L. excubitor following AOU (1998 & supplements), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Garrulus glandarius , G. bispecularis and G. leucotis (del Hoyo and Collar   2016) were previously lumped as G. glandarius following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994) and Sibley   & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Corvus enca and C. violaceus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. enca following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Previously placed in Sylvia (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019). Until recently considered conspecific with C. deserti (AERC TAC 2003, Cramp and Simmons 1977-1994, Dowsett and Forbes-Watson 1993 and Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993) (see related note/s). Proposed subspecies theresae (from Sind, in Pakistan) falls within range of individual variation of nominate. Monotypic.

In past, often treated as conspecific with P. subaffinis, but differs in morphology, voice and habitat; molecular study (Johansson et al. 2007a) indicates not closely related. Recently described form occisinensis (Martens et al. 2008) was originally given species rank, but is virtually identical in song to nominate and morphologically undiagnosable. Zhang et al. (2019) have proposed that the cause of the apparent molecular difference in occisinensis is a rare instance of ‘deep mitochondrial divergence’ resulting from hybridisation of eastward-expanding affinis with a postulated extinct congener, which left a ‘ghost of introgression past’ in the genes of the colonising population. From this and evidence of its undiagnosability, it is concluded that occinsinensis is appropriately synonymised with the nominate. Two subspecies recognized.
Copsychus albospecularis and C. pica (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. albospecularis following Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Previously treated as Garrulax mitratus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cibois et al. (2018). Until recently treated as conspecific with G. treacheri as G. mitratus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993). Two subspecies recognized.
Schistolais leontica (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Prinia leontica.

Previously placed in Sylvia (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Cai et al. (2019). Formerly also placed in genus Parisoma within family Timaliidae, but morphology, behaviour, vocalizations and mtDNA indicate that it belongs in present genus. Monotypic.
Certhidea olivacea and C. fusca (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. olivacea following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Monotypic.

Phyllastrephus icterinus (HBW and BirdLife International 2017) was previously split as P. icterinus and P. leucolepis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016), but P. leucolepis is now considered a junior synonym of P. icterinus. This follows analysis by Collinson et al. (2017) who showed that leucolepis falls within the range of intraspecific genetic variation observed in icterinus and most likely represents a plumage variant of it.

Tangara vassorii and T. atrocoerulea (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. vassorii following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Tangara velia and T. cyanomelas (del Hoyo and Collar   2016) were previously lumped as T. velia following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe   (1990, 1993).

Tangara cucullata and T. versicolor (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. cucullata following AOU (1998 and supplements); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996). See T. argentea. Hitherto treated as conspecific with T. cucullata, but differs (in male) in its pale chestnut vs chocolate-brown crown (3); more russet wash to bluish underparts (1); buffier, less greenish tone to hindcollar, mantle, back and rump (1); bluer tinge to pale turquoise-green wing fringes and tail fringes (ns1); larger size (effect size for bill 3.02, score 2). Monotypic.
Xenodacnis parina and X. petersi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as X. parina following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Xenodacnis parina and X. petersi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as X. parina following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Aphrastura masafuerae (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2021) was previously listed as Aphrastura masafucrae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016). The latter spelling was subject to a later attempt to correct the name by the author of the type description, and has been recognised as an accidental error: the type description had intended to use the name of the island on which the species occurs in the original description.

Acrocephalus luscinius, A. hiwae, A. yamashinae, A. astrolabii and A. nijoi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. luscinius following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Previously placed in Melidectes, now separated with M. nouhuysi and M. princeps in Melionyx, following Andersen et al. (2019) who confirmed a paraphyletic circumstance in Melidectes reported in an earlier study in which the three species above occupy a separate clade; they are also vocally and morphologically distinct, with sooty plumage lacking green wings and tail. The authors propose reviving the genus Melionyx (mentioned in the Checklist genus account for Melidectes) for these three species, and this is accepted here. The three comprise a group of medium-sized species that differ from other current congeners in size, morphology, plumage and voice. Populations across Central Ranges previously recognized as subspecies occidentalis, including Eastern Highlands form gilliardi; but recent study (Beehler & Pratt 2016) noted no discernible plumage or bare-part differences, and size variation is clinal (small in W to large in E & SE). Monotypic.

Previously placed in Melidectes, now separated with M. fuscus and M. princeps in Melionyx, following Andersen et al. (2019) who confirmed a paraphyletic circumstance in Melidectes reported in an earlier study in which the three species above occupy a separate clade; they are also vocally and morphologically distinct, with sooty plumage lacking green wings and tail. The authors propose reviving the genus Melionyx (mentioned in the Checklist genus account for Melidectes) for these three species, and this is accepted here. The three comprise a group of medium-sized species that differ from other current congeners in size, morphology, plumage and voice. Length of bill may vary, being longer in Star Mts. than in Snow Mts.; study required. Monotypic.
Meliarchus sclateri (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Melidectes sclateri.
Gliciphila undulata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Phylidonyris undulatus.
Gliciphila notabilis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Phylidonyris notabilis.
Ceratopipra chloromeros (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Pipra chloromeros.
Ceratopipra cornuta (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Pipra cornuta.
Sylviorthorhynchus desmurii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Sylviorthorhynchus desmursii.
Anabacerthia ruficaudata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Philydor ruficaudatum.
Clibanornis rectirostris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Hylocryptus rectirostris.
Oriolus brachyrynchus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as O. brachyrhynchus.
Urocissa erythroryncha (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as U. erythrorhyncha.

Previously listed as Crateroscelis nigrorufa (del Hoyo and Collar 2016), but moved to current genus following Norman et al. (2018). Both subspecies show marked individual variation, apparently with wide overlap between the two, and species may be better treated as monotypic (Beehler and Pratt 2016). Two subspecies currently recognized.

Previously listed as Crateroscelis robusta (del Hoyo and Collar 2016), but moved to current genus following Norman et al. (2018). Although subspecies form three distinctive groups, these occur in a geographical “leap-frog” pattern that presents a serious obstacle to treating them as three species; a proposed temporary solution of elevating the buff-breasted subspecies sanfordi and bastille to species level (Beehler and Prawiradilaga 2010) was not implemented by the proposer (Pratt and Beehler 2015), who reported that “the songs of the various forms are alike”. Further research evidently needed. Form ripleyi sometimes synonymized with peninsularis (Beehler and Pratt 2016, Beehler and Prawiradilaga 2010, Dickinson and Christidis 2014). Birds from E Owen Stanley Range (extreme SE New Guinea) described as subspecies pratti, here considered too poorly defined to warrant taxonomic separation from neighbouring nominate. Kumawa population may represent an undescribed subspecies (Diamond and Bishop 2015). Seven subspecies currently recognized.

Previously listed as Sericornis spilodera (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) but moved to current genus following Norman et al. (2018). Race aruensis moderately distinctive owing to usually unmarked throat and upper breast, but some nominate birds show relatively weak streaking in this area (2); crown slightly more olive (1) but upperparts barely any paler; few or no mensural differences apparent, and no information on vocalizations. Forms batantae and wuroi barely distinguishable, and sometimes subsumed into, respectively, ferrugineus and guttatus (Beehler and Pratt 2016). Seven subspecies currently recognized.
Gerygone magnirostris and G. hypoxantha (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as G. magnirostris following Christidis & Boles (2008) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Vireo sclateri (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Hylophilus sclateri.
Pachysylvia hypoxantha (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Hylophilus hypoxanthus.

Corcorax melanorhamphos (HBW and BirdLife International 2017) was previously listed as C. melanoramphos (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) .
Colluricincla tenebrosa (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Colluricincla umbrina.
Phonygammus keraudrenii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Manucodia keraudrenii.
Lophorina magnifica (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Ptiloris magnificus.

Lalage melaschistos (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Coracina melaschistos.

Jønsson et al. (2018) establish that Cerulean Paradise-flycatcher Eutrichomyias rowleyi, Drongo Fantail Chaetorhynchus papuensis, Natewa Silktail Lamprolia klinesmithi and Taveuni Silktail L. victoriae belong in a separate ancient family, Lamproliidae, sister to the Rhipiduridae. This finding is accepted here, but it raises the issue of the English names of the flycatcher and the fantail. At present we opt for ‘Cerulean Flycatcher’, to remove the impression that the species is a member of the Monarchidae, but retain ‘Drongo Fantail’ given the proximity of the Lamproliidae to the fantails; but neither proposal is set in stone.
Geospiza pauper (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Camarhynchus following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Formicivora paludicola (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) is recognized following evidence presented in Buzzetti et al. (2013).
Loxops coccineus, L. ochraceus and L. wolstenholmei (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as L. coccineus following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Geokichla oberlaenderi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Zoothera oberlaenderi.
Crithagra ankoberensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Serinus following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Anthochaera phrygia (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Xanthomyza phrygia.
Horornis haddeni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Cettia haddeni.
Chamaetylas choloensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Pseudalethe choloensis.

Myiodynastes hemichrysus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) contains the subspecies minor and cinerascens, which were previously included within M. chrysocephalus. M. chrysocephalus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) is monotypic.

Microspingus cinereus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Poospiza and listed as P. cinerea following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Sylvia dohrni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Horizorhinus dohrni.

Setophaga striata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Dendroica following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 & supplements); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
